AT A GLANCE(Full review follows below)Game Name: Sniper: Ghost Warrior 2 Original Release: 2013 Genre Tags: FPS; Stealth; Sniper; Linear My Overall Grade: B+ Estimated Playtime (Campaign): 5-10 hours Multiplayer Aspect: Auxiliary Recommended To: Established fans of the genre; Game atmosphere connoisseurs REVIEWSniper: Ghost Warrior 2 is a narrow-pathed, story-driven FPS with minor stealth elements.  The campaign is highly story driven and will escort you from scene to scene as you progress; don’t expect an open world, or much freedom to explore in the main game.  (The DLC expansion, however, does provide a more open-world experience).  There is also a multiplayer mode which did have a small number of active players at the time I played this.What I found most enjoyable about Sniper: Ghost Warrior 2 was the main campaign.  I really enjoyed the simple storyline, the pacing of the game, and the landscapes which you explore.  The graphics may not be the absolute best, but I really found the levels to be attractive and interesting.  The story wasn’t earth-shatteringly good but it kept me interested throughout my playthrough.  The story guides you through narrow-pathed levels as events unfold.  Don’t expect to be able to do much exploration or anything; although, there are some hidden collectibles to search for (even then: scarcely off the main path).You are a sniper, so most of the gameplay revolves around moving (stealthily) from one sniper spot to the next, picking off enemies as effectively as possible.  There are stance, breathing, gravity, and wind mechanics that are taken into consideration when you snipe.  And you are supposed to snipe… you won’t be able to "Rambo" through the game, even on easy.  That said, the game is pretty forgiving and has decently placed checkpoints, so even on hard it shouldn’t be overwhelming.  In fact, some people may actually find the game too easy— as the AI is pretty predictable and most scenarios can be swiftly dealt with before they even are aware of your presence.There is also a multiplayer mode.  There were a few dozen people playing at a time on the occasions that I checked it out.  It certainly can have its moments, but when you have a 5 on 5 (or less) of all snipers, it can get pretty dull.  It was a little too slow for my personal tastes, but I am sure it can be quite enjoyable for those who would appreciate the style of PVP gameplay.Sniper: Ghost Warrior 2 offers a fun campaign that will take you on a ride and offer a brief FPS experience focused on stealth and sniping.  If that sounds like fun, you will probably enjoy what this has to offer.  I wouldn’t, however, expect much from the multiplayer experience.Follow my curation page to see more of my recommendations!

												I would give this game something between a thumbs up and a thumbs down because I do like some aspects of the game.  However, they force me to make a black & white choice and I choose "No Way".  The graphics are pretty good, the basic gameplay is OK but there are a lot of issues:1.  There are places on the maps you can get stuck and not be able to get out of AND you cannot kill yourself to continue playing the game!  You have to leave the game altogether and rejoin (if you can).2.  There is no way to kick or ban a player on your own server DURING the game ...you have to wait for the game to be over!  This is the ONLY thing you can do to protect yourself and it isn't even in-the-moment or real-time!3.  Rampant cheating via engineered hacking/aimbot/God-mode programs ruin any opportunity for the expectation of fair play.  I feel as though I have left more games than I have finished because of these jerks.  I wish them all a horrible painful death in the real world.  They have collectively stolen the money we have invested in this game and Steam does nothing to stop it.  Indeed, the cheaters occasionally talk about such things and defend their own actions on the Discussion channels and you never see a Steam moderator step in and take any action.  They have left us to the wolves.4.  The "game-view" or "sight-view" (what you see vs. what the enemy sees) is really screwed up.  I can be inside a tunnel with no view of the enemy yet he can see me and kill me.  How is that fair?  My arms and legs aren't hanging out, I am OUT OF SIGHT and even this is no defense.  Being out-of-sight is not even considered stealthy in a game that is BUILT on concept of stealth?5.  There is no way to configure your own server for "Pistols-Only", "No Pistols" or anything else that would allow different styles of play or game modes for variety.  Every server and every map is largely identical with few deviations.  It quickly  becomes boring.6.  Character movement and control is full of inconsistencies... in some places you cannot go prone for no aparent reason.  Where you can go prone, while you are crawling on your belly you may encounter a flat board or step in the ground.  Crawling across this change in terrain causes you to STAND UP!  Instant death in many circumstances.  Other places with boards or terrain changes this doesn't happen and you pass right through them.  In some places you cannot go prone, but if you hit "Crouch" it instantly goes prone instead.  VERY inconsistent on a portion of the game that SHOULD be rock-solid in its second version.7.  Cheaters/hackers/banned players can just make up a new name and continue playing.  How does this help the integrity of the game?  There is no way to stop them and the game LETS them get away with it for as long as they want.The game was fun when I first started but now is only occasionally fun and the more I play the more frustrated I get.  There are far too many problems, not enough players, too many cheaters and there is NO support from the developer or this provider so I have decided to stop buying ANY more games like this.  Little quality control or standards seem to be applied and the user pays the price.

												An “ok” non-AAA game that provides a mainstream stealth and sniping experience.Presentation and writing are mediocre and clichéd, but I was already expecting this. Otherwise, the story is not bad, and slightly more down-to-earth than most Call of Duty games of late. Levels are very linear and heavily scripted. You are guided by your spotter who stays at your side most of the time. This provides good immersion and manages to convey the sense of working as a team, but his AI is a bit unreliable when in open combat.The scripting is fairly basic and lacks some polish. There were various issues, like dialogue getting cut off, or checkpoints not reloading correctly. A few times my character would confirm over radio that I had the target in my crosshair, but the target was no where to be seen on my screen. The checkpoint save system has the usual irritations associated with such a system. It is also a pity the difficulty settings offer no more options beyond “easy, medium, hard” - I wanted to play “medium”, but without the “red dot” aim assist that ruins the sniping challenge. Also, once you have started, there is no option to change the difficulty later. I had a few crashes to desktop. All these issues were very annoying, but did not ruin the experience.The graphics are decent (as you would expect from the CryEngine) but do not quite have the same visual quality as the Crysis games. Some areas look really nice, but others less so. The standard quality setting are poorly optimised. I achieved much better fps after careful tweaking (tip: put “object detail” on low for massive fps boost and next to no quality loss).Controls are ok, but feel a bit clunky and are unresponsive in some contexts. Fortunately there is no mouse lag or acceleration. Weapon handling and ballistics are ok, but not simulator grade. The game lacks a detailed tutorial and you cannot “zero” the sights to various ranges like you can in ARMA and Red Orchestra 2. The simulation of wind on bullets feels artificial because the wind speed is not effectively reflected in the environment - vegetation does not respond accordingly and there are no other indicators like the sound of wind or moving dust etc. The displayed distances seem to be fake - an ingame distance of 400m is actually closer to 200m (a sin many mainstream games commit one way or another to be more accessible to console peasants). Compared to Far Cry 3, this game was clearly made on a smaller budget, with less content, freedom and polish, but in the end I still liked the single player campaign more here. It is more cohesive and serious, while Far Cry 3 was a theme park of absurd sensationalist violence.Overall this is a decent second-rate game I mildly enjoyed. I had very modest expectations, and it satisfied them. Get it when on sale.

												This game is fun and relaxing while being pretty immersive for the most part. The sniping is enjoyable and the developers manage to keep things fairly entertaining. It looks pretty good using the Crysis engine and it runs fine for me on a GTX 980 with Windows 10. I just have to do a trick to get the vsync working. It’s necessary to enable windowed mode and then switch back to fullscreen mode, everytime I boot up the game. Once I do this, I get a solid 60FPS, with no screen tearing.The campaign checkpoints are poorly implemented, which can force you to sit through the same sequence, multiple times after dying. This is particularly frustrating on the expert difficulty which can be extremely challenging. I found the multiplayer component to be very unique and fun, as it’s a relatively new concept for me. It mainly involves stalking other players with your rifle scope, while not giving your position away. Only problem is that not so many people are playing multiplayer. The DLC maps, which are fairly impressive, had no one playing at all when I tried to find a game.Sniper Ghost Warrior 2 is also surreal and ridiculous in a way that I really enjoy. I mean I don’t know if the developers intended for the voice acting to be so funny. The game appears to be a great example of ‘funny without meaning to be’. As I think they might of been trying to create a serious and realistic tone. However the Commander Wheeler character in particular sounds like a Thunderbird and his dialogue is ridiculous. The voice acting and dialogue, among other things, is pretty hilarious, throughout the whole single player experience.This game is kind of an entertaining mix between guilty pleasure nonsense and genuinely engaging gameplay. Some of the areas can feel a bit empty and under developed at times. However, the focus here is primarily on the sniping mechanics, which are implemented quite well. I also played through the DLC campaign called Siberian Strike and I enjoyed that too.  I had a good time with this one overall and I would certainly recommend that you give it a try.

Posted: September 27, 2014
												Sniper: Ghost Warrior 2 is a superior shooter when compared to its predecessor. Granted, that isn't saying much.City Interactive has addressed virtually all of the sore points that made the earlier game miss as often as it hit. This is an accomplished stealthy shooter, with smarter enemy AI, more-realistic sniper physics, and scaled-down difficulty that provide a challenging, not maddening, sniping experience. Only miscues like the spread-out save checkpoints and throwaway multiplayer keep it from achieving greatness.Most of your time with Sniper: Ghost Warrior 2 will be spent with the three-part campaign. You play as Cole, a special-ops sniper helping out assault teams in hot zones ranging from the Philippines to Sarajevo to Nepal.A well-written, well-acted script give the game a great action-movie vibe, as do authentic-looking visuals and animations powered by the CryEngine 3. Excellent sound effects do a wonderful job of pulling you in. Weapon noises, the shouts of enemy voices, the far-off rattle of weapon fire and various atmospheric sounds like the background are all handled extremely well and enhance the tension as you line up each careful shot.Shooting is also much more enjoyable, whether you're using a mouse-and-keyboard setup or a gamepad. In the earlier game, bullet drops were extreme, slight winds significantly affected shots, and your heart rate caused the scope to carom all over the place. Here, the physics here are just right.Gameplay is now more focused on stealth than shooting. All of the pure action episodes of the last game have been ditched for a more intense sniping approach where you stay hidden as much as possible, only popping out for quick headshots and silent knife kills. That said, there are some shortcomings. The biggest is the checkpoint system, which saves your progress too infrequently.  The joys of stealth are also occasionally dampened by level linearity.Also you occasionally need to play through particularly tricky parts of levels once or twice before learning enemy patrol patterns which is sometimes frustrating.Multiplayer is pretty much an afterthought. All you get is team deathmatch and a pair of maps. Sniper: Ghost Warrior 2's story and stealth make for a satisfying and entertaining single-player campaign. The frustratingly few-and-far-between checkpoints and MIA multiplayer are disappointments, but this is a worthy sniping experience, especially given the game's budget price. Overall 7/10.

												Sniper: Ghost Warrior 2 is a first person shooter that focuses on stealth and sniping and presents itself with quite a couple of improvements over the 2011-released prequel.The story is stereotypical modern first person shooter bla bla. Terrorists try to obtain a weapon of mass destruction and you have to stop them before they get the chance to use it... so, really exciting stuff there. While the story is as generic as it can be, the storytelling and the dialogues, combined with the actual gameplay, work out surprisingly well and keep things going without every really boring you to death.S:GW2 is based on the CryEngine 3 (the same engine used for Crysis 3) and while the original game already looked fairly decent, S:GW2 made an even bigger step forward towards visual quality. The texture detail, lighting and level design of the different locations made me stand still and just look around for a bit more than once.Along with the enhanced visuals, the gameplay mechanics also greatly improved. The AI in the prequel was a horrible pain as enemies would spot you through walls or over a distance of hundreds of meters. Thankfully, the AI was completely re-done for S:GW2, so enemies behave like they should and also show some actual intelligence as, depending on the area, they will try to flank you from all sides or hide behind cover. Additionally, if you break the line of sight or hide in foliage, they will start searching for you.Each of the 'hotspot' areas in the levels provide you with one or more overwatch spots from which you can safely identify your targets and take them out either one by one, 2 with one bullet if they stand in line or even an entire group if you shoot a grenade on one of the enemy's belts. Alternatively, you can also get closer and take them out either with your knife or your silenced sidearm and if you want to be a real Ghost, you just sneak past them so they will never know you were there.As the enviroments change, you will have to utilize your thermal or night vision to progress safely and spot your enemies. While this is a nice gimmick and the night vision is often required in really dark areas, I barely used the thermal vision, though it can help spot enemies that blend into the enviroment or are covered by obstacles. The visions are also pretty much the only gadgets you have and while you get C4 charges during certain key points in the game, it feels somewhat lame to not be able to place Claymore mines and lure enemies into them. Or just blow them up with frag grenades.While the prequel had some action-heavy levels where you actually went head-on towards your enemies and mowed them down with your combat rifles, S:GW2 doesn't feature something like that at all. You have to stick with your sniper rifle as your primary weapon at all times and while the game actually is called 'Sniper', I feel like this strict sniper rifle-only thing killed a bit of the gameplay dynamic and possible replayability of the game as it eliminates the option for the player to replay a level and, instead of silently sniping the enemies, just going nuts with an assault rifle and pumping bullets into everything that moves.I tried to be as stealthy as possible, so the base campaign took me around 6.5 hours to beat. The Siberian Strike DLC, which consists of 3 fairly lengthy levels, added another 2.5 hours on top of it. While a couple people seem to be still playing the multiplayer mode, I can't comment on that as I was never able to join a server and gave up after dozens of tries and a couple attempts to fix it.All in all, S:GW2 is a huge improvement over the sequel and seeing what turds City Interactive has produced in the past (prior to S:GW), it's good to see that they can do something decent for a change. If they keep up this level of quality, I might eventually start looking forward to their upcoming games again.If you're looking for a decent and good-looking sniper experience, make sure to give S:GW 2 a shot (A shot - get it? Because it's a sniper game... hahahaha. Ah, nevermind).

 UPDATE:  I'm not one for giving up on anything, and I REALLY liked the first "Sniper: Ghost Warrior", so I kept at it and eventually found a way that I could play the game all the way through:  "Cole AndersonWe are sorry that you have encountered problems with our latest update. For those who have critical issues with our latest update, please follow steps written below:1. Run regedit.exe2. Choose HKEY_CURRENT_USER3. Select Software>City Interactive>Sniper Ghost Warrior 24. Double click on r-Driver5. Set "Value data" to DX9We are currently working on a solution to this problem. The issue will be fixed as soon as possible.Regards,CI Games support"   Now this was NOT a fix, as I still had several issues with crashes, and the occasional graphical glitch, but I was able to play and complete the game.And so based on that, I'll say that I did enjoy the game overall, and found it to be very much like it's predecessor in just about every way.  Graphics are updated, but other than that the mechanics are exactly the same, gameplay is the same, and I'd say given that the story is pretty much the only thing that has changed, this is more like a continuation of the original "Sniper: Ghost Warrior" than a new sequel.  But, considering how much I liked the first one, that's not necessarily a bad thing.As for the DLC "Siberian Strike", the best part about it was that there was alot less hand-holding than in the main game, and you got to do things pretty much your own way which is certainly a plus.  However, the DLC was barely an update much less an add-on, with only maybe an hour of new story content, and... well, multiplayer isn't even a thought here.  But still, it was more of the same as the main game, so that's not a bad thing.Overall, given the MANY and SEVERE technical issues, I still can't necessarily recommend this game (seriously, NOBODY should have to edit their registry just to get a freshly installed game to work).  However, if you're willing to fight like hell to get it to work, then it is a fun play through that should temporarily scratch your itch for some snipey goodness.  Just make sure you get it during one of the 80% off sales.------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------- ORIGINAL REVIEW: Well, I guess it serves me right.I read all the reviews... mostly good, but some bad.  And the ones that were bad were really pretty bad.  Some examples are:- Bad optimization, so gameplay is laggy- MAJOR crash issues for a significant number of people- Severe graphical glitches that make the game completely unplayable- Big time cheating and client sync issues in multiplayerBut, I really digs me some sniper action, so I went ahead & disregarded those warnings because I thought "Hell, I got a kickass pc that blows the recommended specs outta the water!  Maybe I wont be one of those guys that has those issues".Riiiight.<sigh>Soon as I booted it up for the first time, I found out exactly what that whole "graphical glitch" thing looked like.  Just as everyone described; invisible characters, floating guns, and giant artifacts that take up most of the screen.  Surprisingly, I found a "workaround" for the problem.  Notice I didn't say a FIX for the problem.  No, it wont fix the issue, but I found out that if you cheat the video settings a bit, you can get the glitch to MOSTLY go away (still pops up here & there).Alright, so now that's outta the way, should be good to go, right?Riiiight.<sigh>About 2 mins into the game, right about the time you juuust start to finish that whole hand-holding "tutorial" kinda part at the beginning of the first mission....  "Sniper: Ghost Warrior 2 has stopped working".OK, that's weird..  well lets boot 'er back up & get back into this thing!Riiight.<sigh>Needless to say, I got to experience first hand the same crash issues that everyone else had talked about.  Happens randomly,  generally right when an insignificant action has taken place... like when you shoot a guy.  Cause, you know, you only do THAT once or twice a game, right?Well, in my stubbornness, I continued to try & power through it, hoping that it would eventually go away & I would somehow get to enjoy me some good 'ol snipey action....  and I looked for solutions all over the place and tried different things, until finally I simply couldn't take it any more.  TWO HOURS I tried.  Loading the game OVER & OVER & OVER.  And every time I got going, for no reason (other than... you know... shooting a guy) it crashed every time.SO, all I can hope at this point is that you will not be the stubborn dupe that I was, and you'll resist the urge to disregard the warnings as I did.  And that you will look elsewhere to satisfy that itch in your finger for some sniper action.  Cause let me tell you... the only itch that this game covers is the itch to bash your face into your keyboard.

												My thoughts on Sniper - Ghost Warrior 2:Singleplayer:A linear action-shooting game (duh), where most of the time you either crouch behind bushes/cars/walls/trees, trying to get the perfect shot on an enemy, or walk from one hideout to the next. For someone like me who likes a good Sniper shot from miles away, waiting several seconds up to a minute just for one good shot is okay, everyone else can stop reading here and leave.The game is called Sniper for a reason - because that is what makes 85% of the game. The rest is either running or the occasional kill with a gun or knife. The story is average, nothing big to be expected, but enough to keep the game interesting. I liked the parts where you had to fight your way along a (linear) path, and the game does a good job of giving you the feeling that you're a ♥♥♥♥ing sniper and every shot has to be a killing one. There are some challenging parts but you never feel like there is no way you can make it further unless you really suck at using a sniper rifle or feel the need to blast everything away, because you can't.Multiplayer:Avoid like ♥♥♥♥ing hell. You'll feel like there is a huge♥♥♥♥♥blinking sign above your head while your opponents don't even have a visual model. The game comes with an impressively good soundtrack and nice graphics. If using sniper rifles is what you enjoy most in other shooters this game may be yours, but if you're looking for a fast-paced action game like CoD or CS you're wrong here.Can recommend the basic game, especially when on sale, but not the expansions and the multiplayer mode.

 About Sniper: Ghost Warrior 2Sniper Ghost Warrior 2 does the sniping aspect very well. There aren’t too many FPS games out there that focus on sniping, or at least, there aren’t any out there that have this much depth to sniping. The developers have done a superb job at creating a realistic sniping experience. Various measurements need to be taken before lining up the perfect shot and different locations mean different adjustments. Distance, wind, and even the curve of the bullet need to be taken into consideration. This makes sniping enemies very enjoyable and varied, depending on conditions.Before starting to play Sniper Ghost Warrior 2, my expectations were very high. I was expecting it to at least match the original game in terms of gameplay features. Unfortunately it failed to do this, and ultimately failed to meet the standards of the Cry Engine 3 (one of the most powerful engines currently available).Similar to the way I felt before and after I started playing the game, I’ll start with the good things and move on to the bad things and finish with the best part.The developer, City Interactive seemed to have focused perhaps too much on the sniping aspects of the game, because that’s about all that’s good about it :/ I’ve noticed a lack of gameplay features that were present in the previous game such as, grapple hooking your way to high places, picking up enemy firearms, using throwing knives to take out enemies. The gameplay revolves completely around using your sniper rifle to well……..snipe, and using your P220 pistol if things get up close and personal. The P220 features in all three of the chapters as a sidearm, but the primary sniper rifle changes depending on what chapter you’re playing. Apart from finding the occasional enemy Dragunov rifle, you have no other weapons to find or interact with. This seriously upset me. Release Date: 15 Mar, 2013The Level design Level design is another issue with Sniper Ghost Warrior 2. The levels are detailed, but I feel this is just a way of disguising how painstakingly linear they are. Each chapter has you following a set path with a few open vistas to shoot enemies from a far. The vistas do offer fairly detailed locations to find and shoot enemies, but ultimately they just serve as complex shooting galleries and you never actually get to explore them. The levels are also too small. I find myself disappointed whenever I round a corner, only to realise that I’m in an even smaller house than the last one I was in. I was really hoping for a more open ended level design, but City Interactive has decided to play it safe and keep things way too simple. The Multiplayer	Lastly, I’ll talk about the multiplayer. This is the most surprising part about Sniper Ghost Warrior 2. It’s actually a decent addition to the game. I was highly expecting an equally lack luster experience online as I did with my campaign experience, but it turned out better than expected. Sniping is really the only feature in multiplayer, but it’s easier to enjoy due to the lack of a forced story or other cheesy scripted events. The multiplayer levels are really well designed, plenty of places to hide, plenty of choices for rifles to use, and plenty of intensity that should have been more common in the single player. Looking around the maps for enemies is a long and tiring process, but once you find one and line up the perfect shot, it’s all worth it. Hearing the bullet whizz past your head as another sniper takes shots at you, forcing you to relocate before it’s too late, that’s an awesome feeling too. It’s a nice break from the normal run and gun shooters out there, where the SMG class is king. In this case, less is more.All in All Sniper: Ghost Warrior 2 is a good Action Game!8/10 From MeSweep

												Sniper Ghost Warrior 2 is a stealth action game with focus, as the name of the game hints, on sniper rifles. Single player story offers about 5 hours of entertainment, which actually felt long enough - If the game had more playtime with current features, it would get repetitive.In 10 levels you can expect a lot of linear gameplay, with exceptions like parts where you can choose if you want to go through with stealth or shoot everybody (and somehow survive). But expect most parts being based on stealth, as your only weapons are sniper rifle, silenced pistol and knife - all the time.This action game is one of the most newbie-friendly action games I've seen lately. Even on normal difficulty the game felt easy, it's hinting you every 100 meters where you should move next. And most of the time you will be on action with your partner (invincible NPC who doesn't do much damage) who will be signalling exactly what you should do - shoot this bad guy, move there, beware of the spotlight etc.I was actually surprised that for a lower priced action game, Sniper Ghost Warrior 2 felt good and had a great atmosphere, made thanks to surprisingly good visuals and well done voice acting. Even the story, though it's not something complex, was interesting and made the game into something more than just another corridor shooter with optional stealth.Sniper Ghost Warrior 2, unlike the previous part, deserves full recommendation if you don't mind the linear gameplay and shorter length. Even those looking for multiplayer might have get some fun there, as I've seen few active deathmatch servers with players. So, what are you waiting for? Take your sniper rifle and go to war!

												The game feels like a Call of Duty knock-off, but even more linear if you can believe that. When you're not moving from shooting position to shooting position in rail-shooter fashion, you're probably in the middle of the incredibly anti-climactic "boss fights." The end of the game comes just as swiftly as it did in Sniper: Ghost Warrior; one second you're shooting some bad guys and the next thing you know the credits come up leaving you unsatisfied and annoyed.As for the sniping aspect of the game, it's ridiculously easy on the the easiest and medium difficulties. When I first noticed this I had attempted to switch to expert difficulty and I was initially happy with it. At normal distances the kills were challenging and I couldn't pop off 10 perfect headshots without breaking a sweat like I could on medium difficulty. But as soon as I was faced with the task of picking off targets from 1000 meters away (some requiring quick action with as little as a 3 second notice) the game became borderline impossible.So in conclusion: the game is incredibly linear and unsatisfying. If the game had a more open feel like that of the original Sniper Elite and allowed for some actual drama in the plot I'd be more than comfortable giving it a positive vote, but sadly that is not the case.

content:
Posted: April 23, 2015
												Coming into this game from Sniper Ghost Warrior 1, I wasn't expecting much. I gave that a negative review even though I tried very hard to like it, but comparing this game to its predecessor blew my mind.Let's start listing some things. I'll be combining Pros with Cons since some things offset each other.+The graphics are BEAUTIFUL. This game running on Cryengine puts its predecessor on the Chrome engine in the dust. +The story in this is slow to start going, but once you get into it you just want to keep going. It's very immersive and intriguing and I wish it was longer.-The point of 'longer' is true. I beat this game's campaign in 4 hours. Hardly enough time to enjoy everything the game had to offer.+But what else did it have to offer? Well the general gameplay mechanics are much better. The mission flow is much smoother. There are much less gameplay bugs to be found in this game. It makes it predecessor look half♥♥♥♥♥♥♥in comparison.-However, the game does suffer from a severe lack of optimizations. For one, the V-Sync does not work. For two, the game suffered so many graphical glitches on DX9 that it was rendered unplayable. DX-11 ran correctly, but not as smoothly. With my beast of a rig I was only able to mantain an average of 50 fps (Meanwhile I can run games like Arma 3 with well over 120 fps). Lastly, I experienced one CTD while playing the second mission of the first act. Not sure if its a common thing or a one-off, but I feel obliged to mention it.- The multiplayer is eh. It's just two teams staring at each other across the map, taking shots at each other, while one guy on each team is running around rambo as if this is call of duty, and at least one person is smack-talking every other person in the match. It doesn't do much to extend the life of the game. A co-op mode would have really helped this game.Overall this game blows its predecessor out of the water. I'll give this an 8/10 for what it is. If it was properly optimized, if the story was a bit longer, or if the multiplayer was really worth playing, it may have earned a higher score. This is still twice the rating I gave to its predecessor, and so I would definitely recommend picking this title up whenever you get the chance.

												A mediocre realistic FPS game, with some minor graphic bugs, glitches and very short singleplayer campaign. Only buy it when it goes on sale.My Rating: 6/10The graphics are actually good enough to not hurt your eyes playing it, but compared to the popular Sniper Elite series, this game is a no-go. I also had to play it with 15fps (sad) and I'm not really sure what caused it since my graphic card isn't that old... I'll just blame my pc for that. Overall, this game's graphics are on par with some other sniper games, considering its release date.The story plot is great, although the campaign is too short that it only took me around 5 hours to complete it. The AI is somewhat badly programmed, I even got an alarm raised because of the AI failing to take down a single enemy at a medium range. Some of the enemies only stand behind a cover not shooting you until you peek far enough to let them notice. Other than that, the realistic sniping effects are great, the controls are easy to learn, the sounds are realistic, the smoke puff needs a bit improvement, and I honestly think that the pistol is too accurate to even be a 'pistol', it's a 1-hit to the chest and very accurate at long distance, if you aim correctly on the target. I even think you can even finish this game with just pistol. Overall, this game mechanics are good enough but still needs improvement.My comment on this game? I crashed 2 times on this game, so please do not buy this game until it goes on sale cuz it's probably not going to worth the big price for the bugs and glitches this game has. Only buy it if you have nothing else to play and you want to buy and play this just for fun.ps: the kill-cam is epic

content:
Posted: July 20, 2014
												3 years after the somewhat mediocre first episode, City Interactive completed its job on the sequel. Was it for the better or for the worse? Well, let's see it!---Graphics: This certainly is an improvement! The game looks stunning with the CryEngine. I still think the first episode's graphics were decent but City definitely made a good choice by licensing the 3rd iteration of the CryEngine. Water effects and the jungles / lush forests look simply stunning.---Campaign: Unfortunately, no changes here. The story is still very, very shallow; sections are quite repetitive and the campaign is overall very short. SMG / rifle sequences are now completely eliminated - this is now good as they were very irritating and made the game very difficult. Finally, emphasis is really on the titular sniper shooting and nothing else! There is now an urban (Sarajevo) and mountain (Tibet) area to make the story more interesting. This is all good but as mentioned the new campaign is also very short. Also, you can easily see how heavily the story mode is scripted: you can only go where the designers intended for you to do so.---Multiplayer: Very few levels available for you to practice sniping on. Also, I am not a camper so lying on the ground for extremely long minutes to see something happen is not my cup of tea. It is overall very slow-paced; once you have found the best hiding - / vantage points on the levels available there is nothing else to see. I still do not know where to put Ghost Warrior. The 2nd episode is better but still a very short, mediocre experience for gamers out there regardless of their affection towards sniping. Good sniping can be found in the Sniper Elite franchise which does offer much, much more.

Posted: April 3
												I really can't whole-hartedly recommend this game. It is an enjoyable enough sniper game, especially if you're looking for a cheap alternative to Sniper Elite or the like, but damn does it have its flaws. Get ready to hear every one I can remember.First off, you might as well ignore the story. Spoiler alert: every character they focus on besides the player is a back-stabbing traitor. There are literally 3 traitors in this one game. The guy giving orders before/during the missions is your typical "Dammit man, get it done at all costs! I don't care about your emotions!" obnoxious military general. Just to drag it out, on multiple ocassions you have your finger on the trigger about to do the deed and captain-impatient tells you there's no time and you have to do something more important.The cutscenes are full of bad voice-acting, worse motion-capture, and half are entirely useless. At one point you're knocked out and taken hostage during a cutscene. You wait for a second cutscene to load and play  immediately  afterwards, wherein you wake up and get punched in the face and knocked out again. Riveting stuff. All in glorious 480p resolution. Oh, and when you wake up from capture and free yourself, you immediately find a handgun which your character specifically comments has 4 rounds in the magazine, you kill an enemy right outside the door, he drops his assault rifle right on the ground and you can't pick it up. Just brilliant.The gameplay and AI is just horrendous. During one mission, your first target is a sniper who's standing (yeah, standing) in a bell tower, totally motionless. I take the shot, bullet passes right through his head, no damage, suddenly everyone in the whole town knows my GPS coordinates. Eff this, reload last checkpoint. Try again, this time the bullet goes THROUGH HIS FACE, blood splatter and everything, he falls out of the ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ bell tower AND LIVES. My character comments something to the effect of "Dang, I missed and now he knows I'm here." 'KAY. Reload checkpoint, try again, exact same outcome. No idea what's wrong with this game.And for a sniper game that involves a lot of crouching and prone, they sure as hell made it impossible to do that. Let's say Z is crouch and X is prone, right? If you're crouching and hit the prone key, nothing happens and nothing indicates that your posture has changed. But when you hit the crouch button again, you go prone. Press crouch again, you stand up. Crouch again, you crouch. Press prone twice while crouched, you stand up. You wind up just pressing Z and X in random patterns to eventually wind up in the position you were looking for. It makes no sense at all.As for the missions, for more than half you are hand-held by an ally as you follow them needlessly-close to enemies and have no choice or challenge in taking a different route or finding your own way. It's just bad. Let me sum up how the game plays: During one mission, you go through a parking garage packed with hostiles. You are tasked with shutting down the lights and sneaking out using your night vision while the enemies are blind. You have one route to take to the fuse box, thereby forcing you to perform a scripted knife kill along the way. Stab enemy (the stealth kill animations are also atrocious btw), look to the right, remember the lights are still on at this point, there's another hostile not 25 feet away looking right at you with no visual obstructions, and he doesn't notice. Alright then. Proceed to the fuse box, RIP THE WIRES OUT BECAUSE THAT'S HOW FUSE BOXES WORK, and head for the exit. All the way to the exit, you can pass 5 feet in front of enemies and they can't see you because it's pitch black. At one point I thought "There's no way I can get past this guy, I'll be 2 feet from his face, I'll just kill him instead". Wait for the area to be clear of other enemies, stealthy knife kill from behind in the inky black darkness, suddenly EVERY ENEMY KNOWS I'M THERE AND CAN MAGICALLY SEE ME, I get lit up and die next to a rusty old car.That's this game.4/10

content:
Posted: February 21, 2016
												Heyyo, it's a pretty decent game tbh. It's not a AAA Game like Sniper Elite series (The WWII sniper game by Rebellion) but it definitely holds its own. :)The sniping? Well, since this is a sniper game? I guess that should be discussed first heh. The game takes into account bullet drop, wind direction, stance, elevation and stamina (how many beats per minute your heart is doing) so the mechanics are all there ok. The bullet cam is very much like Sniper Elite, but no model damage on the enemies. They just flop over. There's also the hold shift to slow down time and make it feel more movie-like and make it easier to hit moving targets. If you sit in sniper/scope mode long enough? The game gives you a little red circle to show where the bullet will hit and highlight when ontop of an enemy... so as a sniper game? It's good... but Sniper Elite feels more rewarding when you land a shot since you see what kind of damage you're doing.It has a decent enough storyline... Quite generic tbh but it was good enough for me to want to finish the game.The voice acting is also nothing flattering but works good enough to make me want to finish the game.The Gameplay? Eh, after playing Sniper Elite and Sniper Elite V2? Gameplay isn't as good as those games. There's no disguises and trying to sneak around... the campaign is extremely scripted where you spend most of it doing exactly what your spotter tells you to do or you die.. speaking of which? Once enemies start hunting for you? The AI will definitely 360 no-scope you at close range. Super annoying when I try to ambush them and as soon as they rush through a doorway? Bullets hit me before their character turns around and I'm dead... so that's seriously annoying lol.The graphics? They're pretty darn good, definitely not the best on Cryengine but I'd say a step above State of Decay (another good game built on Cryengine).The music? Eh, I think there's only three or four songs for the complete game as most maps feature the same songs... They're ok I guess.Sound effects? Well? Since most of the game you're only using about three different guns (silenced pistol, silenced sniper rifle and a long range silenced sniper rifle) for the whole game? There isn't that much variety in sound effects. The sounds that are there are pretty good though.My Steam account says I beat the campaign in 5.2 hours and the asking price is $21.99 CAD... so that equates to $4.22 per hour. I don't plan on playing multiplayer since I'm not much of a multiplayer FPS guy these days I guess. So do I feel like it was worth $4.22 an hour? Kinda I guess. It was fun enough... but there's some older games with a longer campaign for the same asking price that'll give you more entertainment. I'd say get the first Sniper Elite game and see what you think of that game before buying this one tbh. Maybe the same with the first Sniper: Ghost Warrior game.. but of course I don't own that so I can't directly give my opinon on that game, but this one is ok so I'm guessing the first Sniper: Ghost Warrior is also ok.

												I don't know which one has been the worst game i played through so far in my life but this is pretty damn bad, even on my standards.First of all the game liked to crash while launching every single time approx 4-7 times before launching. When i first actually launched the game i saw message stating follow another characted called Diaz and Diaz was a floating gun in midair and nothing more, enemies were invisible as well which (i don't think i need to even say this) was pretty damn difficult to get the game actually started... I checked some forums and found out that the game needs to run as DX11 so i started the game once more and checked the optionmenu and the game had DX9 as default. Well this fixed the graphical problems luckily for now. If DX9 causes so much problems, maybe the game should run a DX11 as default, or after several complaints they could've fixed the problems with DX9.Anyhow.... I played through Act 1 and thought i'd give it a rest for the day and get some sleep. Next day i started up the game once more and continue on Act 2, only to notice the complete lack on audio, except on the cutscenes. (Also apparently a very common problem which you might be able to fix or then you can't... People have asked for patch to fix this from the beginning, no answer or patch/fix from the developers so far.)For some reason the game itself likes to swap between windowed and fullscreen mode whenever it wants and throw the ingame menu-cursor in the game making the game unplayable (Only way to get rid of this problem is to reboot the game, and if you're in a place where you haven't yet reached the next checkpoint and you're playing on expert, you're going to hate these situations.One last gamebreaking/pantsripping/ragequitting situation in the game itself was on Act 3 when you were supposed to snipe out the helicopter pilot. The game itself ran perfectly on maxed out graphics (Was also on default) before this point. When you were supposed to take out the copter the FPS drops to unbearable levels. Well then it's onto options, changing the settings, reboot and take out the helicopter pilot.Finally i think i can talk about the game itself. The graphics look quite nice actually, eventhough you are looking everything through the sniperscore mostly.  Audio.. well i can't say too much about it since they didn't work after first act. In Act 1 they we're quite pleasant eventhought the guns were far from realistic.Story is pretty generic for a FPS and especially for the sniper series. You have a baddie, and your job is to end his life. I was playing the game on expert and i have to say one other thing i actually liked about the game is the "realistic" sniping system where you have to take notice to the wind and distance if you want to hit anything. What i wasn't extremely keen on though was the A.I, (If you're in a ghillie suit 3 km/2 mile away from the enemy, lying in a bushes and take a shot towards an enemy who is facing his back towards you and can't even see any gunflash or whatever its called, you happen to make a miss, he will absolutely screw you over by turning around, kill you in oneshot with a pistol or any gun he's having. It's just ridiculously difficult from time to time to continue in this game especially with some maps and huge distances between checkpoints.That's all said and done, I really can't suggest this particular game to anyone before it has been patched and fixed.

Great sequel to the first game.What bad I have to say about this is the actual shooting. In  hardest difficulty the red reticle is taken away and you have to judge the correct shootingpoint yourself. This, however, is not easy. The red reticle shows where to aim and it takes the wind and distance in account. However when you don't have it, things get tricky. I spent an hour in shooting range trying to figure out the measurements in the scope and they don't make sense. For example: The distance to target is 800 meters and wind is 6 m/s to the left. I aim to point where these conditions are matched perfectly. And when I fire, I miss the target. The bullet goes way over the target and is pointed too much to left. In this case, the correct aiming point was 400 meter distance and 2 m/s wind to left. So the indicators in the scope are for nothing. You just have to guess. Besides that shooting thing, this is great game. And if you never play with hardest difficulty, you never have to think about that detail. I still recommend this game. The game is true to its name and is fun to play. But if there was anything else wrong, I wouldn't recommend this.

content:
Posted: July 19, 2016
												"Sniper: Ghost Warrior 2" is one of those games that gets a few basic mechanics very right, but also sometimes trips over its own feet.All by themselves, the stealth and marksmanship bits are well executed. When you're given the maximum possible opportunity for those two elements to have free-reign, your patience and cunning will be rewarded.The problem, though, is that you don't get the maximum opportunity that often. "Sniper," rather like other CryTek-based offerings I've experienced, has this tendency to just herd you along from tactical problem to tactical problem. When you get right down to it, a title that should land heavily on the side of "wide open area" seems to get choked down to what amounts to "room-corridor-room-corridor-room..."It's just that the rooms are a bit bigger than average, and the corridors might not have a roof over them.There's also an overarching issue of mild to moderate identity crisis. A full-blown sniper game, in my view, demands a very freeform experience. However, "Ghost Warrior 2" seems to try to do the tightrope walk between that and a scripted, "Call of Duty-esque" ride. What this does is subvert the overall experience, in both subtle and more troubling ways.An example of the subtle variety is knife kills. Sneak up behind a crouching enemy, get in range, and...guess what? There's only one animation for "backstabs," and that animation requires the enemy to be standing. So, somewhat hilariously, triggering the kill results in the opponent helpfully standing up so that the animation can run.Something like that is mostly funny, but you can also end up being aggravated by the more serious problems. I once got set up for one of the "shooting gallery" sections such that one of the must-hit enemies was obscured by the platform the player character was occupying. There was no way to move, so I was stuck with the scripted position. I made three blind shots before one of them connected. A more regularly experienced issue was the pickiness of the level geometry. Something about the crouched and prone collision models seems to get a little weird, with your character "hanging" on invisible obstructions for no apparent reason. More than once, I would be trying to crawl past some enemies, only for my character to claw helplessly at the ground because there was some debris on the ground no more than 1 inch high.There's also the metagame issue of there being no player-driven save. "Sniper" is all based on checkpoints, and there aren't  quite enough of them. They also have an alarming propensity to occur just before some tedious dialogue that precedes a touchy bit of action. Make a mistake, get killed, sit through the exposition, make a mistake, get killed, sit through the exposition, rinse, repeat.A game like this is all about solving combat puzzles that take time and patience. The appropriate save system for that is one that's player directed. A checkpoint progress system is for run-n-guns, where a setback is likely to be measured in seconds rather than minutes. It doesn't get too terrible, but it's still the wrong mechanic for the game type.But! But, but, but...The game is definitely good fun, and I do recommend it. It just has some rough edges, which you can learn to forgive pretty easily.

content:
Posted: February 17, 2014
												If you want an experience that makes you think on your feet, adapt, improvise, and overcome, DO NOT play Sniper: Ghost Warrior 2. I had hopes that they would have improved from the first game, I was wrong. I played the game on hard difficulty right off the bat. The game was easy since they held your hand all the way through. So, really there was no tension within the gameplay to keep you on the edge of your seat. Not to mention, the story isn't even worth reading in a book, much less have it play out for you within the game. Basically, the gameplay consisted of sniping from a fixed position, and then moving on to the next position, then repeat. The most challenging sniping segment comes in the first act of the game, which consisted of 3 acts. The gameplay involved in moving on to the next position is very boring, since again, they hold your hand the entire time. It tries to be a mini game of stealth during these segments but fails miserably. Think of those goofy shooting gallery games at a carnival where you just stand there and try to hit as many targets as possible, combine that with amazing graphics from Cryengine 3, and that's pretty much the game in a nutshell. In my opinion, a sniper game needs to be non-linear mostly where tactics play a large role in how well the mission turns out. I have played Sniper Elite (love it), Sniper Elite V2 (could've been 100x better), and Sniper: Ghost Warrior 1. Out of all of them, Sniper: Ghost Warrior 2 would have to be my least favorite. However, it does have the best eye candy. If this game used the non-linear style of Sniper Elite combined with the Cryengine 3 graphics, it would've been an amazing experience. I did play the DLC Siberian Strike, however, it was only a minimal improvement over the main campaign's gameplay. I didn't even touch the multiplayer, I had no desire to do so. I apologize to the game designers and production team for a bad review, but you deserved it. Games are to be active experiences, they are not to be passive experiences where the option of choice is a minimal factor. Obviously, this game was made just to serve as a way to make some money by cashing in on the masses playing other shooters or possibly to give some new people a chance at making a game with a great engine to design it from. The graphics were upgraded very well compared to the first SGW, but the gameplay was worse than the first in the series. 2 annoying oranges out of 5

Posted: January 4, 2014
												I advise not expecting too much from this game.(The following review is only about the single player campaign.)As its name suggest, Sniper Ghost Warrior 2 is mostly around sniping, and all about infiltrating.Sniping is quite challenging since distance, gravity and wind affect your shots. Luckily, out of Expert difficulty, a red dot appears on your crosshairs indicating where the bullet will land. Your best shots can even be seen from a bullet traveling perspective, which makes this quite entertaining.Sadly, there are still many improvements to do.Stealth is not very reliable, since plants sometimes hide you and sometimes not, like with some hard obstacles. Unless with a teammate AI guiding you, it's often better to eliminate all enemies before crossing the area.AI is pretty simplistic, your teammate often not covering you, enemies staying hidden while they can't locate you or run towards you when they spot you, not caring about your allies.Some gameplay is pretty frustrating, like not being able to switch between crouch and prone (you must be standing first), nor to switch weapons when aiming down sights. Maps are fairly long and decently detailed, but also show some problems, like some obstacle close just enough to block your way or preventing you from advancing while prone. Including corpses.The story is quite cliché and not detailed. The many cutscenes don't help it and are here mostly trying to give an epic feeling, but pretty much fail to do so. It's also disappointing said cutscenes are pre-rendered videos, at low quality, and sometimes laggy (not joking).Overall, it's decent game if you want some sniping experience, if you have some time to spare waiting for something else.

content:
Posted: March 21, 2016
												CI Games are slowly getting better at putting together a sniper game.  Art of Victory was a dogs dinner, Ghost Warrior 1 had it's problems that held it back firmly in the realm of average, and this one is just crossing the threshold into "worth your money".  Not full price money mind, but on heavy discount it's worth it.They have thankfully gotten rid of the terrible non-sniping parts of GW1 (you can't even use an assault rifle in this game) and this is a purely snipe oriented game - as it should be.  There have been improvements to the AI and there is now an indicator for when you are alerting enemies.  The gameplay is purely linear, there are no options to go off the beaten path, and some sections fell very hand-holdy with your spotter telling you exactly what to do and when when it is painfully obvious what you ned to do anyway.  Enemies are fairly ruthless if you let them get anywhere near you, and avoiding alerts is certainly the way the game is meant to be played.There are a few annoyances, the cutscenes are in a really crappy resolution and don't look good, stealth killing enemies with your knife can leave you unable to move as if stuck due to a clipping issue for a few seconds, and there are a few points where dialogue will be delivered twice, or too early for the set piece it's attributed to.  The game also remains a short one, shorter than GW1 clocking in at around 4-4.5 hours.  The story is of course nonsense as well.If CI Games continues to improve, who knows, maybe a GW3 will actually make the cut at above heavy discount prices.

content:
Posted: November 2, 2014
												If you liked the first you will like the second. If you didn’t then there is little here that will likely change your mind. The formula is almost the same but the pacing and level design are much improved. In fact, level design, graphic style and the locations for each act are extremely well done. Each has a different atmosphere and feel that helps build tension and excitement. It is a shame that SGW2 is actually so short a game. Given time and resources you can only wonder at just what City Interactive might have achieved. Whilst there are limited choices in terms of level exploration it is painfully evident you are playing an on rails shooter. You never really shake the corridor shooter feel and the ever present way point indicator only serves as a reminder of just how much you are being funnelled through the game. The stealth elements of the game are not infuriatingly complex or overly sensitive to the slightest misstep. However, the few times stealth becomes the play style of choice it is more often than not because it might serve as an easier alternative to simply running in guns blazing. Once again, the lack of a more open world with multiple paths to your objective is more the culprit than the actual mechanics for stealth which are generally pretty good. You just never really have the space to truly explore options to avoid more of the combat.The AI is largely there to be killed with minimal fuss and will provide token gestures of resistance whilst being as accommodating as possible to someone armed with a sniper rifle. This is, however, a relative blessing. Were it more proficient in trying to kill you it would only prove just how mind-blowingly useless your spotter is at trying to aid and protect you.Hidden secret items make a return and each act will have a different item to look out for and collect. That said, I’m not at all certain what bonus or benefit you gain from spending time looking for them beyond satisfying any OCD tendencies you might have. The single player campaign offers up about 4 hours worth of entertainment so this isn't a game you'll be with for long unless you're planning on spending time with the multiplayer. The multiplayer is entertaining and certainly, so far as I was concerned, offered far more for my money. Whilst I enjoyed playing through Sniper Ghost Warrior 2 I also felt cheated out of my money. The game is just too short, offers to little in the way of gameplay and left me simultaneously wanting more and glad I gotten it out of the way. Wait for it to appear in a 50% off or better sale before picking up. At full price there are better sniper games and certainly better FPS games available. As a cheap title picked up in a sale to enjoy as a multiplayer game amongst friends between more time consuming or in-depth games, it's a game I'd strongly consider. With the right people SGW2 could potentially be a lot of fun though ultimately it will only ever be a game that you play every now and then.

												Ehhhhh...where to start...Ill start with good points first.Sometimes good gameplay e.g. long range good sniping, nice layout to get stealth kills.Good cinematic kill cams.Good graphics, except for the cut scenes they just didnt look as nice and the characters eyes...THE EYES!!!! (you will see what i mean if you buy it).Now for the baaad.Story was super uber lame.The AI was so annoying and inconsistant. 1 minute you will be hiding in the shadow right in front of them and they wont spot you then the next minute some guy 1000 meters away starts shooting at you. However this keeps changing sometimes you get a sniper aiming down the sight at you from 400 meters and they wont spot you but some guy will spot you behind the next wall. The AI on a good note though is they weren't super stupid just buggy aaand they just reacted waaay to quickly to their friends being shot in the head. The cutscenes. The EYES...THE EYES MAAAN!!!!! YOU WERENT THERE!!!!! trust me if u buy the game just skip the cutscenes theyre♥♥♥♥♥♥graphically and its a♥♥♥♥♥♥story.The multiplayer. "♥♥♥♥ OF YOU CAMPING NOOBS!" Ok so it would be fine if it was just camping I guess but what makes it so annoying is half the people glitch out the map. It takes no skill if you see a non glitcher because the red ballistic circle is there and your name pops up in massive letters if they aim close to you.The missions are inconsistant difficulty. Ok so was playing the first few levels, playing on the brightness that was the most realistic, didnt go well kept walking into walls, I was think well shiit this is hard. This is the first level whats the next one gunna be like...it was simple, waaay to easy, then the next one got difficult again and that just went on and on. They kinda decided to mix it up in the middle and throw in a "you cant use stealth here" mission where you had to kill AAA guns. THE GAME IS CALLED GHOST WARRIOR!!!! WTF!!!! WERE!!!! YOU!!!! THINKING!!!!!The objectives were buggy. Sometimes the objectives didnt show up, sometimes they did and they would lead you to exit the mission area. Sometimes the commands given were stupid and unclear "target those sniper on the building to the east" *finds one sniper kills**cant find second sniper because he is chilling to the west*.Final point. The wind meter was sometimes hard figure out what side the wind was blowing.OK so rant over. Personally I did enjoy this game but I wouldnt recommend it. It is so clunky and dodgy that I doubt you would enjoy unless you like the sniping.

content:
Posted: December 31, 2016
Sniper: Ghost Warrior 2 is a great game, however is notorious throughout the community for having a whole lot of bugs and graphical glitches. I'm pretty sure that at least half of the guides in the Community Guides section for this game are about how to fix the many variations of the infamous "Black Screen Bug".There are two versions of this bug that I have come across personally, and in this review/guide I will be explaining how to fix both of these - or at least the method I used.Bug 1) Invisible NPC's + Black Walls/Objects Around the GunThis first bug is caused simply by the version of DirectX the game is using. This can be easily fixed by, once in-game, going to Options > Video > Basic and changing the DirectX version from DirectX9 to DirectX11 from the main menu. If this method does not work for you, then I'm sorry, as this worked for me and I am using a AMD Radeon R7 260X graphics card which isn't exactly the worst graphics card out there, but certainly isn't the best.Bug 2) Black Screen After StartupThis second bug is much more common, but is slightly harder to fix. To fix this bug, go to the place where your Steam folder is located (commonly found in Program Files x86, but if not then it will most likely be in Program Files). Then, go to Steam > steamapps > common > SniperGhostWarrior2 > Game and either delete, rename, or move the "_FastLoad" folder. After completing these steps, you may want to restart Steam just to be safe. The game should no longer provide a black screen at startup.If you found this review/guide helpful, then please vote up, so others can easily find and use this guide.

												Sniper: Ghost Warrior 2 is one of those games with a lame plot, but managed to keep you playing nonetheless because the play mechanics are quite solid and the satisfaction of having that bullet meet the bad guy is just so... satisfying. There's a lot of shooting to do, as you've been sent to go after lots of objectives, multiple locations, and you'll have to do plenty of stealth work as well, as you sneak past guards, silent kill sentries, make your way past sniper alley, and much more. Multiplayer can be a lot of fun too as you try to sneak your way to flags and whatnot. It It's a bargain for the amount of satisfaction it brings.

content:
Posted: December 7, 2015
												For me, this game was definitely worth what I paid, although I did purchase it from Bundle Stars for around $3, still a great game. There were only two things that really irritated me about the game; one being that sometimes the matchmaking either didn't work or was dead, even though it was an active part of the day, and what annoyed me the most was the poorly designed hitboxes that activate cutscenes. This hitbox issue even occured on the final kill of the game that is the most 'climactic' kill of the entire game, even I could see that my bullet missed yet the cutscene still went on to where the target died. Whilst multiplayer matches were sometimes difficult to find, once gameplay inside of them initiated, I always found it very unique as the game, at first look, has a very similar genre to the Call of Duty series, yet the multiplayer is so different from any other game I've ever played...it's snipers only. So yeah sure, it is basically 'Campers v Campers' but it still works without being majorly irritating, even though some people are CRAZY good at it.TLDR: The game can of course go with having some work done on it, but for a quick and unique game to play, it was definitely worth my $3 and could be worth your $20 if you don't like saving money, although I personaly wouldn't have paid $20 myself because I do like saving.

Posted: December 13, 2015
												Excellent game that took me completely by surprise. It requires strategy, unlike a lot of other campain driven games. For instance, you take down the enemies that are not in line of sight of each other to remain hidden. If you are spotted you are in trouble and things become a lot more difficult, but you do not automatically fail. You can also choose to sneak around enemies and leave them alive, or take them out from close quarters. This game is absorbing and highly entertaining. Don't expect a story like Call of Duty, or an insane graphical masterpiece.Want a true challenge? Harder difficulties remove the aim dot. You need to check the wind strength and range, and then align your shot accordingly. This game mode immerses you even more.The serbian strike DLC was great, but shorter than the main campain (as expected). I have not played much of the multiplayer yet. There are a couple of servers that are active. Proper sniper battles.  I will buy the sequel, if there ever is one.

content:
Posted: February 18, 2014
												-SINGLEPLAYER-This might turn out to be a review for the awesome parts of the first game because, let's be honest, the first game was so much better than this. What were they thinking?! Let's talk about the story first - one word: Lame. It was so short and there was no obvious point to everything you were doing. It was so hard to follow. Oh, and just so you know, I review a game on it's gameplay, not on its graphical quality, although, I gotta say, the graphics were absolutely outstanding! However, that was really the only good thing about the game. The feel of the game with the sniper rifle and running around felt very clunky, even for a PC game - and where I would get around 60 - 80 FPS on high settings, I would still get this really irritating stutter glitch/bug (Had an FPS counter in top left corner of screen).There was no sence of freedom to make your own decisions about infiltrating this place or killing these people. It was far too easy because you had that really annoying spotter sitting next to you the whole time telling you how to do it. No thinking is required. Also, it is without a shadow of a doubt THE MOST LINEAR GAME IN THE HISTORY OF GAMES. No exaggeration. You couldn't make the decision to go left or right to get to your location, no open-world aspects, all you could do was follow your spotter. I felt like a baby learning how to walk whilst playing this game. I could often guess what was going to happen next half the time. WHERE IS THE FUN IN ANY OF THAT?!The story all felt very cliché and hollywood movie esque. By that I mean it had three very American protagonists, played by, what sounded to be, low budget - somewhat amatuer voice actors. And so on, blah blah blah. You could finish they campaign in just under 4 hours if you rushed it, which to be honest, I did because it was so boring I just wanted to get it over with.-MULTIPLAYER-The multiplayer for Sniper: Ghost Warrior 2 was all round extremely dull. There was nothing good to say about it to be honest. It's what you would expect from a sniper-based game: lots of camping, spending an age to find a target to shoot at, and when you eventually do find a target, they either move before you can get a shot, or you are shot first.-OVERALL VERDICT-Pros-Stunning Graphics-(Reasonably) Clever AICons-Short Story-Boring Story-Cliché Story-Same-old Story-Clunky feel when playing-Repetetive-Dull Multiplayer (full of little kids squealing on the mic)-NO WHERE NEAR AS GOOD AS THE FIRST GAME-ADVICE-Don't buy this game - spend your money on a better game, for example: The first one!Thanks for reading.

												The shooting range is the best part of this game, although it is not a standard shooting range. The shooting range is in of itself a single map that one selects a gun (and can swap them out) and then gets in position and snipes the actual targets... they are not cardboard cutout but actual 3d characters that are mobile. Wind is a factor in the game as is distance (gravity).The campain for this game feels rushed. The gemetry/maps are built well (only had one instance that what diisplayed and what was got me... which was nice (every game has at least one if you explore as I do). The thing that makes it feel rushed is that there are many isntances where it says shoot X and I have no idea where X is, and they jsut keep repeating shoot X... which is especially difficult to look for when you are being shot at. Sometimes they effectively say what to target and where, most of the time they do not, however sometimes they are marked for you... Finally there is one instance where you have less than a second or 2 to snipe a very mobile target that if you don't hit you must retry it again, and again, and again... by the time I got it I think I quick scoped without any expectation of hitting the danged target... and in no way could effectively repeat the success.It is not a bad campain or game, just can just lack its entertainment value at times. If you can get this game for real cheap then go for it, otherwise I would not go out of your way for it. Cheap for me would be a buck or two... or grab it in a bundle of some sort if that is more economical for oneself.

content:
Posted: January 10
												I have played the whole singleplayer campaign on casual and have thoroughly enjoyed it. The singleplayer is split into three parts called acts the first act is set a couple of months/weeks ago the second is in 1993 and the third in the current day. Through the first act you and your partner 'Diaz' are picking off men and guiding your soldiers through enemy territory. The second act you and your partner Gomez do the same sort of thing (later theres a twist), in the third act 'Diaz' is back and you take down a double-crosser in an amazing finish.The games graphics are better then average considering it came out in 2013. It has a more then decent story and even on casual difficulty its certainly isn't a walk in the park. The animations are farely good but you won't get to see many of them in the demo (which I recommend playing before purchasing the full game). There are barely any cutscenes in the first act but in the third act they take up easily 30% of the gameplay. There are a number of negatives but most people over exaggerate on how bad they are. For example if you are walking through a forest path you might get stuck on an invisable object for a second. One thing i found interesting was in different scenes 'Diaz' was voiced by different people. Last issue I have is that they didn't sync the character's mouth animations with the words they were saying which looks odd. I haven't played the multiplayer much at all and I'm not a big fan of what I played but I never had high expectations for it. I suggest playing the demo before purchasing it. Now the price; I bought this through the Sniper Ghost Trilogy pack for $2.99 US at the christmas sale (without sale it is priced at $19.99 US). I don't recommend that package because the older Sniper Ghost games aren't nearly as good as this one and plus the new one is coming out this year. By its self this game costs $9.99 US which might be a little pricey but if its on sale its a great pick up (it will probably go on sale soon because of Sniper Ghost: Warrior 3 coming this year). I want to point out that its not a complete copy of sniper elite thats a little worst for a cheaper price. I think people got this idea because of the slow-motion bullet cam that are very similar in both games. The system requirements definitely aren't crazy considering you don't even need a single gb of ram to run it. A tip of advise, when following Diaz or Gomez to dodge enemies they might walk into an area where you would think they would get spotted. Don't then take another path around the area because it looks safer because you will get spotted somehow so just always follow them whereever they go in those parts of the missions.Lastly the singleplayer will last you a few hours with the great highlights and the multiplayer is average. I was disappointed that it only took about four hours to finish singleplayer I really wanted to continue playing more missions (e.g. don't expect plenty of hours of gameplay). I rate it 8/10, I would of rated it higher if there were less bugs and glitchs but I rated it this high because it keeps you on your toes the whole time.

content:
Posted: January 1
												Really, this is an awful game. Your spotter spots out everything for you so there is no question on where enemies are, and if there is no spotter, then you die by the first mistake that you make. There is no option to get rid of the assist dot in the scope, so you are forced to play a pretty boring campaign that makes sniping seem like the easiest job in the world. Even the dialogue was pretty terrible, with soldiers arguing with their superiors, and some pretty forced jokes. I honestly felt like this game could have succeeded as it employs some interesting gameplay mechanics, but the campaign is boring, the story is uninteresting, the AI are so stupid yet can charge you and kill you easily if discovered, the characters are dull and have very forced personalities, the sniping gets old and mechanical very quickly, the dialogue seems like it was written in a middle-school 6th grade english class, there were too many times when I died not knowing why...etc. I only played 99cents for the game, so I'm not asking for my money back. It's important to understand that I'm usually willing to give sniper games a try, but this one fails on many levels.
