content:
Posted: April 4, 2013
												Before starting to play Sniper Ghost Warrior 2, my expectations were very high. I was expecting it to at least match the original game in terms of gameplay features. Unfortunately it failed to do this, and ultimately failed to meet the standards of the Cry Engine 3 (one of the most powerful engines currently available).Similar to the way I felt before and after I started playing the game, I’ll start with the good things and move on to the bad things and finish with the best part.Sniper Ghost Warrior 2 does the sniping aspect very well.  There aren’t too many FPS games out there that focus on sniping, or at least, there aren’t any out there that have this much depth to sniping. The developers have done a superb job at creating a realistic sniping experience. Various measurements need to be taken before lining up the perfect shot and different locations mean different adjustments. Distance, wind, and even the curve of the bullet need to be taken into consideration. This makes sniping enemies very enjoyable and varied, depending on conditions.The developer, City Interactive seemed to have focused perhaps too much on the sniping aspects of the game, because that’s about all that’s good about it :/ I’ve noticed a lack of gameplay features that were present in the previous game such as, grapple hooking your way to high places, picking up enemy firearms, using throwing knives to take out enemies. The gameplay revolves completely around using your sniper rifle to well……..snipe, and using your P220 pistol if things get up close and personal. The P220 features in all three of the chapters as a sidearm, but the primary sniper rifle changes depending on what chapter you’re playing. Apart from finding the occasional enemy Dragunov rifle, you have no other weapons to find or interact with.  This seriously upset me.Level design is another issue with Sniper Ghost Warrior 2. The levels are detailed, but I feel this is just a way of disguising how painstakingly linear they are. Each chapter has you following a set path with a few open vistas to shoot enemies from a far. The vistas do offer fairly detailed locations to find and shoot enemies, but ultimately they just serve as complex shooting galleries and you never actually get to explore them. The levels are also too small. I find myself disappointed whenever I round a corner, only to realise that I’m in an even smaller house than the last one I was in. I was really hoping for a more open ended level design, but City Interactive has decided to play it safe and keep things way too simple. Lastly, I’ll talk about the multiplayer. This is the most surprising part about Sniper Ghost Warrior 2. It’s actually a decent addition to the game. I was highly expecting an equally lack luster experience online as I did with my campaign experience, but it turned out better than expected. Sniping is really the only feature in multiplayer, but it’s easier to enjoy due to the lack of a forced story or other cheesy scripted events. The multiplayer levels are really well designed, plenty of places to hide, plenty of choices for rifles to use, and plenty of intensity that should have been more common in the single player. Looking around the maps for enemies is a long and tiring process, but once you find one and line up the perfect shot, it’s all worth it. Hearing the bullet whizz past your head as another sniper takes shots at you, forcing you to relocate before it’s too late, that’s an awesome feeling too. It’s a nice break from the normal run and gun shooters out there, where the SMG class is king. In this case, less is more.Overall I did enjoy Sniper Ghost Warrior 2. While it didn’t meet my expectations, it still does sniping better than any other game I’ve played. I can see myself continuing to play the multiplayer, while waiting for the DirectX 11 patch to be released. I might get 10 more hours out of it if I’m lucky. If you’re a sucker for FPS games like me, this will be worth your time. If not, then you won’t be missing much. 6/10

content:
Posted: March 18, 2013
												One thing is certain: Sniper Ghost Warrior 2 is certainly more enjoyable than its predecessor. But is it that much better if you look closer ? No, but there are a few things that have been improved. First of all, the game now runs on the CryEngine 3. It's definitely visible as the game looks more vibrant and detailed, but faces are still a bit low poly. And the environments, while they look frequently beautiful, are still not open. The game lets you walk in only one direction, so, like the first one, it's still linear. Not a big deal at all, but it would've been cooler if you had the chance to kill people from more than one location.Another improvement is that it's more stealthy. In the first one there were a few moments where you had to kill (waves of) enemies using regular weapons, which was a bit odd considering the fact that it's a sniper game and it's called Sniper Ghost Warrior. SGW2 fixes that problem. You still get to switch to your handgun, but there are no other weapons besides that one and your trusty sniper rifle. Firefights are more intense because of that. Now, intense might not be the right word for it, because they aren't really, but you get the feeling you're playing as a real sniper. And while kills aren't as satisfying as sniping someone in Sniper Elite V2 it still does a good job of mixing up the action with some slow motion bullet kills. Even if they're not that spectacular.The game consists of three acts, with several missions in each act. Missions will take somewhere between 10-30 minutes, and most of us will finish the game within 5,5 hours. It's not overly long and therefore stays enjoyable all the way through.If you're into sniper games, like me, SGW2 might be worth your time and money. It all depends on how much of a fan you are. Still, if I had to choose between this game and Sniper Elite V2, Sniper Elite would win without a doubt. That doesn't mean it's bad, but it does mean there's still room for improvement.[Rating: 70/100]

												So, I'm familiar good shooters. Nothing beats these mechanics. I'm a LEM in Matchmaking for CSGO, and was once in high-ish rankings in TAM ladders for ut2k4. It was a very nice change of pace from the other shooter games I've ever played. A little slow and the linear aspect was not fantastic, but I hear the next iteration in their series is supposed to be open world, so definitely count me in for that.Would recommend to friends.

content:
Posted: February 13, 2016
												In short: A good game but do not buy full priced.Pro's-Nice gameplay if you like sneaking and sniping. Defenitely better real 'sniping' experience than for example Sniper Elite. It tries to be somewhat of a sniper simulator but can't really deliver there like ARMA does. However in the context of this game it is enough to make gameplay very interesting and even challenging. -Pretty decent graphics and nice environments.-Story not very good but interesting enough.Con's-Badly optimised. Although my computer is absolutely fine (can run all games i know at high/very high) this game did not feel fluid. Especially when running it felt weird, a kind of stuttering or something. -Bugs. This game has its share of bugs. Usually nothing game-breaking but i once could not pick up my gun and the keys to change stance seem to randomly make you crouch, stand or go prone which is very annoying.-VERY VERY Linear. you don't have any choice to do anything. You can complete the objective in one way and no other.-Voice acting is a little dull sometimes-That red dot. The only thing making this game a challenge is aiming. With the red dot enabled (when looking through your scope it gives the exact place you are going to hit) there is absolutely no challenge. There really should be a way of disabling it without having to play on the hardest difficulty. The same goes for the hints and everything. -Companion AI is bad. When following a companion they always run. I could barely catch up with them and usually i just played my own style and they would just stand and wait out in the open until i catched up. ConclusionIt is a decent game for a few hours of fun. It gives a pretty good sniping experience where your skill will matter (if you play on hard so disable aim assist). It defenitely immerses you in the role of a sniper. Get it when it is in the sale and you will not regret your purchase

content:
Posted: January 20
												I got the game for 1€, considering that price it was okay... but for anything above 5€ that I'd say you would do yourself a favor by passing this and getting something else. It's trying hard to feel like an AA game, but it's B-classiness is so obvious everywhere. AI is horrendously dumb even on expert levels, game has some very weird design choices and is very, very linear.My "favorite" design choice is that in certain levels you just can't sneak through - you have to run around map looking for that one final enemy to kill before you can progress... that's a big NOPE in a game that's supposedly all about that stealth gameplay. Not being able to pick up enemies guns is very immersion breaking, as is their extreme ability to see you through the foliage at times, and not at others.Story is predictable, cringy and despite all that dramatic feeling you won't really care about any of that stuff that is happening. Voice acting is poor and very out-of-sync mouth movements don't help either. Besides character models and cutscene animations game looks good though, it better should considering it's running on CryEngine.This is the first City Interactive game I managed to finish and somewhat enjoy myself at certain times. That alon is a huge achievement. Maybe Ghost Warrior 3 will be actually good. Right now it's just... a 5/10 territory.

content:
Posted: July 19, 2014
												I enjoyed this sniper game, and I think you'll like it if you generally enjoy this type of game.  It took me 8 hours or so to complete the single player mode on easy difficulty.  Since I'm not a great player, it took some time and retries to clear the missions,  Having checkpoints to avoid starting over each time I died was good, but sometimes I wished there were a few more checkpoints, because there were a few times where I had to replay the same tedious or annoying parts over and over because I kept dying before reaching the next checkpoint.The story here is broken up into three acts, each made up of a few missions, and you're working as part of a team even in single player mode.  I think the story developed well, and even though game play can be a little slow at times (e.g., sneaking into areas means crouch-walking for a long-ish time), I think that helps get you immersed in the story.  I think your only weapons here are a sniper rifle, a pistol (I think), and a knife.  While the knife is useful for doing silent kills, I don't think I ever really used the pistol.  The game kind of seems designed to keep you using the sniper rifle, which makes sense.  At a few points you have to set up on a sniping point from which you cannot move at all, which makes things a little more difficult if you get spotted and shot at, since you can't slide over at all to try to keep the enemies from guessing exactly where you are.  There are multiple difficulty levels, though I haven't tried any but the easy one, and a multiplayer mode, which I also haven't tried.  But the multiple modes and difficulties should make this game accessible to all sorts of players.A few notes on this game (SGW2) compared to Sniper Elite V2 (SE2), which I played before this:  easy mode in SGW2 doesn't mean line up the enemies directly in the center of the cross-hairs like it does in SE2; there is bullet drop and wind effects, but there's a kind of aim-assist mechanism where a small red dot appears showing you where the bullet will go -- you line that dot up with where you want to shoot.  As noted above, although the game play in SGW2 is a little slower, I think I got into the story more.  You don't have as many weapons/tools here as in SE2, but then again, you're in a team here and solo there.  Also, it seems easier to stick with the sniper rifle here; a number of times in SE2, enemies would get close enough that I had to switch to another gun, but that didn't happen very much in SGW2.  Both games are good, but operate a little differently (as expected).

The only things I actually enjoy are the moments when you get to find a vantage point and pick away at enemies, while adjusting for wind and gravity etc. That element is kind of fun. Apparently there are things to find, judging by achievements.. but the game seems to actively discourage you from exploring. It's so straightforward in what you have to do, and the checkpoints are either needlessly close together or stretched oddly far apart. This forces you to replay some pretty boring areas again and again if you fail. Nobody wants to crawl on their belly along one side of the map again. That's pretty much what passes for stealth in this game. It gets old fast.There is also very little variety in options and gear, it's just your rifle and pistol. You can pick up ammo (which you won't need) and medkits (which you'll rarely use - maybe more useful on hardest difficulty?), but can't pick up enemy weapons or have any real variation in your combat. If any enemy is face to face with you, you're pretty much dead in a second. You are so slow and gimped it's a bummer.Granted I'm only on Act 2, but I'm pretty much done with this game. It's just too annoying to play, and the good parts don't make up for the bad.

content:
Posted: April 25, 2014
												It's a rather controversial game. In my opinion, it's far better, than its only rival, the SniperElite v2, but it doesn't make it good. The graphics are okay, the story is ridiculously simple (and bad), but the athmosphere of the game is more or less good.The creators learned from their earlier mistakes. Not learned enough, but learned. The game finally more good than bad, and I find this improvement promising. Finally enemies can't see you from 200 meters while you crawl under a bush, and most of the times they act like a human being... No, that was a little strong word for it, so let's just say they smarter than the CoD enemies.And why it isn't an especially good game? First of all, sometimes it's anoying as hell. There are many times, where the save point is before some unskippable scripted event, and we have to watch it over and over again if we couldn't be succeded at the first time. And there are situations where we have to try a section for a several times, because it's literally almost impossible to find who do we need to shot. The levels are bigger, than they were in the first game, yet they still too linear, and too much part of the game we have to follow our spotter, who (by the way) doesn't worth anything when it comes to fight. If there are two enemies, he helps us to kill one of them, but other than that, he almost never shoot, and doesn't even cover our back. Luckily the enemies see that he's such a ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥, so they don't shoot at him, even if he runs past them. And the last problem is that the game is rather frustrating sometimes. The best example for it is the final "bossfight" if we can call that this way. We have to fight with our nemesis, a traitor, an other US sniper, which is literally means the following: we are proning at a lookout, and searching the area to find him. That's all. Sometimes he shoots at us, so we have about 30-45 seconds to find him, before we die. The tricky part is, the area is FRAKIN' huge (imagine an area which is about 250-270 degrees wide, and there are buildings between 300 to 1100 meters), and the boss shows himself only when he shoots. Of course we can't move to an other spot where he don't know exactly where we are. The game doesn't even let us to let go the riffle and take a look without the scope to see the glimpse of sunlight of the enemy's scope. So the final bossfight is only about luck. If you don't watch exactly the same spot, exactly the same time when the boss shoots at you, you won't find him. If you are lucky, you find him at the first occasion, if you are not, you'll try a hundred times, and you still won't see him.They put multiplayer in the game, because nowdays even a frakin' SIMulator of a CITY can't live without multiplayer, so how an FPS could be? It was just a waste of the precious worktime, because doesn't worth a damn. Snipers against snipers, so it's boring-boring-boring. A co-operative multiplayer might work, but the competitive one isn't a good choice for this game. You literally watch the area, looking for enemy snipers, and you are happy when... no, not when you kill someone, you are happy even when you finally see a player from the enemy team.Since there aren't many competitors for SGW2, I recommend it but not for everybody. If you are a usual FPS player, then you won't like it. It's for sniper fanatics only, and even they won't be satisfied with it, but as I said: there aren't many games with this theme :/

content:
Posted: June 11, 2014
												I got this in a bundle for $3, and it was totally worth that price. The singleplayer campaign is really unpolished, but there are some parts where it gives you a bit of freedom and these are often quite enjoyable. The game is also reasonably comitted to the sniper angle, and does it fairly well. You only ever get a sniper rifle and pistol, so you have to be stealthy. Occasionally, you actually have to think about the best way to accomplish that, and these sections are generally pretty good and evoke the patience and planning of a skilled sniper. At other times the game forces you into gunfights, and these suck. Enemies can kill you very easily, which is good for a stealth game but frustrating in an action game in which you have very little short-to-medium range firepower, since your pistol is crap and your rifle is always scoped and bolt-action. Still, a cautious and skillful player can avoid the great majority of these, so it's not a huge problem. About the plot, not much can be said. Dull military bros shoot a bunch of dudes, and somebody's evil, and more dudes are shot. One level is set in Bosnia, which is pretty cool. I have no idea how historically accurate it is but it's nice to see some new settings being explored.The game looks okay. It's got some nice CryEngine-y effects, but a lot of the assets are kinda fugly. Ultimately it gets the job done. Some of the level design is well-done, but checkpoint spacing is often poor, and manual saves are not allowed. Bugs crop up from time to time, everything from bullets passing harmlessly through enemies to your companion's AI simply not triggering, but it's not completely game-ruining.Ultimately this is only for people who really like single-player shooters. It lacks the polish and bombast of stuff like Call of Duty, but it also lacks the flexibility and openness of games like Crysis or Far Cry 3. Still, for a budget developer it's a pretty solid release, and bodes well for a third game. I wouldn't recommend it at $20, as it's just not polished enough, but for $10 or less it's worth a shot.

												I bought Ghoset Warrior 2 in the STEAM winter cell and its quite a good game considering what I paid for it.  However there is not a lot of content to it in the single player campaign so it only gives you a few hours of play time.  The missions are very linear, which is fine for a game from 10 years ago but the majority of games have moved away from this.  Its also very prescriptive - your spotter tells you which guys to take down in which order.  The main difficulty is to account for distance, windage and your own body shake, This all leads to a very realistic sniper simulation but it does not work so wel IMHO in terms of stimulating game play.  I did not mind the fact that the enemies are also deadly accurate and you die very quickly if you loose control of the combat area by missing too often.  For me the main downfall is that its not a game where you have to think - once you get the rifle dynamics the game is too simple.

												I got this game on sale, and must say I'm happy I did.The single player is simply okay, not the best story though. I encountered a few bugs and glitches in my one run-through of the campaign, and the game crashed once. The kind of glitches/bugs I encountered surprised me for being a finnished product: Once I got stuck between a bush and some branches which required me to load to last checkpoint, another time I got stationed with a heavy sniper rifle, but the "professional sniper" decided to station himself too far from the ledge, so my view was blocked by the ground I was lying on. That can prove problematic for aquiring targets as I'm sure most will understand.I haven't tested the multiplayer since there were no servers online that I could see in my browser. But it worries me that someone has managed to achieve 150k kills, with 100 % accuracy and all of the kills have been headshots (source: Scoreboards in-game). That gives me reason to believe the game is badly protected against hacking/cheating.I won't reccomend this game unless you get it on a good sale or for free.

Posted: April 13
												Tool up, dumbos! Here's the deal... We're Americans, so we're the good guys. They (any other nation, but heavy accents obligatory) are clearly the bad dudes. So, camo on, scope lids up.  Let the banalities begin!Maybe I'm alone in this, but I like games to have at least made some attempt at a moral issue, where the sanctity of life presents at least a crumb of doubt in what you are doing. Shooting peoples' brains out is simply less fun when you start thinking, 'well what did he ever do to deserve that? How is it helping this imagined world if I stick an unapologetic slug through two brains at once? He's just a guard, probably on a zero hours contract, trying to get by, and I'm going to knife him in the neck. Bummer.'The other thing is, if you play a character who is already highly trained, a 'special ops' uber-killer, there's no way up from that. Gordon Freeman was a gentle scientist who expanded his skill-base. If you start at the top, where can you go, narratively speaking?Sniper Elite at least has that WW2 setting, so even though Karl Fairburne is a one-note macho dullard with all the wit and wisdom of a folding trench shovel, you still feel you're fighting evil. Anything based in the 21st Century, especially involving US forces, you feel sort of faintly sick, being part of some over-funded bullying world police.Why can't the hero be Swedish? Or from Belgium?   These problems would be solved by not being so goddam Tom Clancy about everything. Or by maybe having a level where you merely have to serve Halal lunch through the slots in the doors at Guantanamo, just for some perspective on your life choices. Instead of an end of level boss, you could meet Henry Kissinger and get lectured on why covert, illegal military operations in other peoples' countries are actually good for the world.

Posted: October 16, 2015
												Why have I only played 2 hours of the game to write this review? Because with all the hand-holding and narrow pathing, I was litterally bored to tears and just started to sprint around.In those 2 hours, i was bombarded with countless pet-peeves: Obscenely narrow pathed, more narrow than the sight of your scope.Missions are all hand holding, guide you through (shoot guy A, then guy B, then guy C).AI is moronic with clusters of enemies, or rather zones where you kill everyone over by this house, then sneak through the jungle a little more, kill everyone at the next zone. AI does not communicate between zones and all AI uses their indoor voices when you've been spotted. No stealthy "oh where'd that shot come from lets coordinate and look around, while alerting our teammates to a potential threat", it's "you blew your cover, we, the AI in this zone (and only this zone, never mind the guys just around the corner), know EXACTLY where you are instantly". Zero challenge. Be it in stealth, shooting, or decision making, there's no challenge to be had. Bullet mode, randomly the game will think you've made a good shot, and will swap your view to follow the bullet and give you a close up of the crappy sprite blood splatters (the first sniper game had better effects) Plays more like a movie (or a shooter-arcade game)  than a stealth game (lots of cinematic, or scripted sequences, like melee stealth kills: "oh let's pause your control while you watch your character do some fancy melee stealth kill for 15 seconds).  Movement is EXTREMELY clunky. Countless times when I am trying to sneak around the jungle and have gotten my toe stuck poorly formed terrain. Or press <action> to climb things, but rarely displays when you need it. ... Was this even play tested?Graphics are appalling on ultra settings, everything within the narrow path is fine but if you step an inch out of that path (and I do mean litterally on the other side of that bush, near your foot), it's N64 perfect dark- style graphics.Motion blur that can only be disabled through config file editsIf there are any redeeming factors in this game, I'd did not see enough (if any) to keep playing past the two hours I put in (3-4 missions in, POST tutorial).

content:
Posted: December 27, 2016
												This game is ok, if you like endless running, little to no skill required, and just a few seconds of a real sniper experience at the end of each mission. Despite my 2 hours in the game, I didn't even get through Act 1. Each mission takes about 40 minutes-1 hour. If there was more actual shooting to do, it would be better, but it is mainly run run run, take one shot, run some more, crouch and hide until this group passes, run more. You have a silenced rifle, there is no real need to try to wait for sounds to shoot due to the silencer on both your sniper rifle and your pistol. You pick up an enemy's rifle? Oh, it has a silencer too, and it is an auto-sniper. Hit boxes are insanely easy to hit. You shoot the guy in the knee? He dies and flips back 3 feet. You shoot 2 guys with 1 bullet, through one's shoulder and into the next guy's groin? Nice job, they both hit the ground silent. Sniper Elite is harder, the original one, not even counting the sequels. If you have hours to waste, and are only mediocre at the genre, get the game and give it a playthrough. If you are accustomed to bullet drop and wind having large factors, and not having a silencer at all times, then you might want to look for a different game. Whichever you choose, just remember to have fun with what you are playing. This game just wasn't fun for me.

Posted: January 19, 2015
												This game is a medium-good sniper game with above average graphics but also some contras which pull down the character of the game... __________________________Mentionable points+ Above average graphics+ Nice and realistic guns and shot-physics- Multiplayer works but many bugs- different guns depending on version bought__________________________Graphics - 8/10 graphics and weather, enviroment, sunset, water-reflection... all really nice made. Works good thanks cry-engine 3Sound - 7/10Sound is very nice. specially the gun sound - surround. only 7/10 because the sound sometimescrashes and you have to restart the game to get sounds and noises back (reported by several gamers). AI - 7/10The single-player AI ist also well done. Some very rare bugs / senceless movements but overall good made.Ingame enviroment possibilities - 6/10The enviroment is seems nearly most of the time just basicly done. there is no additional door to open or another path to go. no other guns or equipement to pick up. sad.complexity - 9/10The game is easy to understand and after you made a few training shots in the training mode (takes really just few minutes) you are ready for the game.Single Player - 7/10The storyline is okay. nothing with a real "wow" effect but also not boring.Multiplayer 4/10Well the multiplayer is really something that could have done better. First: LAN doesnt work. So no matches via LAN or Tunngle-LAN.Then there are some cheaters/wallhackers. not too many, but you will find some on the servers. the possibility to kick them from the server is weak: you can only kick them in the end of the round (for 5 seconds), and even this possibility took months until the developers involved it after huge (!) complaints in the forums.The normal internet connection game works very well and you will still find always few people online- dont be confused if you dont see servers or see very less servers online. The reason is: Full servers are NOT shown in the server list, because you cant join them anyway - Last: there are much too less maps. basicly there were 3, then there came 2 more and with the dlc another 3-4 more. but after short time, you find out that less than 10 maps is really a weak service.The rest of the MP works great. Also weapons with different characteristics (look up my guide in the SGW2 Forum) and sounds are nice.Price 3/10 Price is definetly much to high. I wouldnt pay 40 EUR again for this. The game is not that "cheap", but 20 EUR for this, including all dlc's would be a good deal.

Posted: July 10, 2016
												Rubbish. I thought it'd be ok, an improvement on the original. But it's not, it's utter crap, and it is definitely not worth a single dollar. Buy "Sniper Elite 3" instead.Here's a list of why you shouldn't buy this:-Ugly as sin. The effects suck, and the textures are repetitive. -Feels awful. You'll think the game is lagging. No, that's the movement speed, the laggy mouse input.-Worst of the Call of Duty clones. You'll get ♥♥♥♥♥♥ pseudo military dialogue, walk from location to location. Just running down corridors. Then shoot some enemies with♥♥♥♥♥♥AI, but they're not even interesting or convincingly bad, they're just poorly pathed, stand still.-Enemies can however see through foliage, which sucks.-Stealth system relies on hiding in foliage and hoping the enemies will pretend you're not there. -Checkpoints are miles apart. -Slow mow kills aren't even nice to look at, come on, it's Cryengine, you can do better.-You won't give a ♥♥♥♥ about the story.-Encounters are boring.-Enemies will psychically know their mate is dead.-The bullets do NOT use a proper physics object, which means that leading targets can be useless.Basically, there is one reason you want to play this. Long range sniping of enemies running from place to place with the killcam, and decent spatter effects, and entertaining locales. Instead, you have protracted "stealth" sections which fail to do the All Ghillied up bit, they're slow, they're boring, you have no real creativity, and it's linear and again, boring as hell. This is most of the game. You could cut it and it would be better.Most of the levels are clearly unfinished, you'll blast the couple of lazy enemies in a second, and you'll run on to the next area, it's rubbish. You'll get to a location for a proper bit of shooting, then back to square one. And the rego will still suck and you'll feel like you have cancer using it.Don't pick this one up. Pick up "Sniper Elite 3" instead, it's not a perfect game, but it's better than this.

												tl,dr: Shooting feels good, but the other gameplay elements are♥♥♥♥♥♥and the game is buggy and inconsistent.So I kind of liked the first Sniper: Ghost Warrior, the only bad taste I remember was the ending which was a little underwhelming, gameplay wise.I am strictly going to talk about gameplay because the story is just some Modern Military shooter garbage.The actual shooting is alright, the pistol (your secondary is able to kill in one shot, unless you are in combat then it sometiems takes two) and the sniper's rifle oneshots aswell, unless you shoot people in their hands. It feels pretty good to line up a shot with a decent range and some wind and just place a bullet in centermass.However, the game is quite buggy and the checkpoints are odd and inconsistent.In one of the earlier missions you are placed in a high advantage point with a very high powered sniper's rifle like a .50 cal or something. Not only do people not hear the shots even though it is only 300 meters away, but I was actually placed slightly below the surface on which I was supposed to lie on.The stealth is weird and inconsistent sometimes you can just hide in some slightly shadowy area and you are completely invisible to the enemy whereas other times they can see through planks and bushes. It may have something to do with playing on the hardest difficulty I am not entirely sure.The point that made me uninstall the game, was when I was supposed to shoot a pilot (inside a helicopter) from a decent  range and good amount of wind, but I only had like 4 seconds to do so giving me time for like 2 or 3 shots. I failed and had to do a bunch of stuff again, failed again and now the checkpoint was right next to the pilot-sniping, however I had no weapon so I couldn't even try it.

content:
Posted: December 7, 2013
												I avoided this game for some time because of the poor early review scores.  I can't comment on whether the inital reviews were justified or the extent of any bugs which were subsequently fixed.  What I can say is that this is not a bad game.  I've played through the single-player campaign (about 7 hours) and the Siberian Strike DLC (about 2.5 hours) and had a fair amount of fun doing it.  Overall, I thought it offered a nice, if over the top, narrative and reasonable stealth / sniper mechanics.  Much of the criticism of the game centers on its linear nature.  On that count, it's guilty as charged.  You will never confuse this game with Far Cry 3 in terms of open world mechanics.  That said, there are plenty of games that offer a fun experience in a linear fashion.  While the encounters are essentially all set-piece they are nicely designed.  I'm still not sure what the campaign was doing in Tibet, but it was terrifically rendered.I'd define the highs and lows as follows:Highs:Solid graphics (better than average PC options for a port)Good sniper gameplayReasonable level of player decisioning (no penalties if you decide to alert the enemy rather than being stealthy)Logical controlsGood range of difficulty levelsEssentially bug-free as far as I could tellLows:A little shortA wonky checkpoint or two (nothing game breaking)Occasional unaware enemies (walking past bodies with no reaction)Overall, I had a good time playing through the campaign and DLC and will probably do so again.  If you are looking for a sniper game specifically, I would probably recommended Sniper Elite: V2 over this one but only by a small margin.  If you catch this one on a periodic Steam sale for less than $10, I wouldn't hesitate to pick it up along with the Siberian Strike DLC.

												Just started to play. Selected medium difficulty and game is very, very heavily scripted. By "scripted" I mean the game tells you where to look, what to shoot at. It even goes up to locking your view so you cannot stray aside too much when aiming or using binnoculars. I hope on maximum difficulty this is not present, because it's so scripted it's starting to disgust me. Graphics are okay, since it's Crytech engine. Tried on both an old and more powerful PC, and it works nicely on the old PC. Voice acting is good, sniper support role is not bad, but the amount of scripting and linear action is very heavy. Unless MP is good, I dont really see much replayability on this game.If you come from harder sniper games like the Sniper Elites series, this games adds a more modern view of sniping but you _must_ play on hardest difficulty level. Otherwise, it feels way too scripted, with almost no choice of targets and how you approach them. On maximum difficulty level, it's ok.

Posted: May 29, 2013
												Dispite the harsh critics I tried this game. People were complaining about the graphics. I got to say I like the graphics in this game. Perhaps they haven't maxed all out but the gameplay is what counts for me so It's good enough. The sounds and music fits the game. I love sniping and being a marksman in first person shooter games. This game has it all. Slow pace stealthy gameplay is what I love doing. This game simulated a "sniper team" with a spotter and a sniper. The weapons caches are all focused on sniper rifles. There are a few sniper rifles to choose from and there is just a limited number of rifles to choose from.  There is a simple story but that is not why I bought this game in the first place. If I want a good story there are multiple quantity of books and movies that suit my needs for that. The maps in the campaigne seem a little linear compared to for instance roleplaying games. But remember this game has been made with a far less budget then for instance "the big" companies like EA (of the blockbuster Battlefield games) or Activision (Of the blockbuster Call Of Duty games) can use. You will still get a few hours of insteresting piece of action with this game. If you are into the sniping gameplay this is a must have. If you want to have a game simular to the blockbuster games you should stay away from it. I have it and enjoy it.

												Surprisingly good. Although a short game (only three mission arcs that are all relatively quick), it does provide what's written on the box - A game focussed around being a sniper. It has a good mix of sneaking and shooting, and the levels where you don't have a spotter are suitably challenging. Playing it on anything less than Expert is a waste, since the bullet impact indicator makes long range sniping far too easy. Pulling off a 1,400 metre headshot on Expert mode is, however, suitably satisfying.The graphics are absolutely astounding. The third mission arc is set in a Nepalese monastery, and the scenery looks straight out of a travel book. That said, I'd not expect anything short of gorgeous on the Crysis 2 engine.

content:
Posted: July 13, 2014
												Solid sniping mechanics and great graphics brought down by bland protagonists and an extremely linear experience.  You play as several different characters and use a variety of rifles, but there was no difference between any of them (well, OK, the rifles each held a different number of bullets.  Which is at least more variety than the main characters had to tell them apart.)With a few exceptions, every mission has you being led by an AI spotter who will tell you when/where to move and when/whom to shoot.  Fall behind and the spotter will yell at you to catch up, speed ahead and the game will stonewall you.  Either with a dead end where you can only proceed once your spotter catches up and tells you what door to open (yes, really), all enemies suddenly on high alert (even if you're in the same place your spotter would tell you to stand 3 seconds later), or a straight up "mission failed for no reason" screen.Shooting targets out of order would have a similar effect.  All enemies would suddenly go on high alert (even when shooting lone targets out of sight of anyone else) or enemies would be straight up invulnerable until you went back and shot everyone in the order the game wanted you to.The few sections where you are separated from your spotter really show how much this game could have shined as a stealth-sniping-action-shooter hybrid.  There's one part where your spotter gets captured and you set off alone to rescue him.  You run through several arenas where you can engage multiple enemies at your own pace.  It really really underscored how good the game could have been, if only they'd given the player some freedom.Ultimately, there is too little player input required and the game is too linear to recommend to anyone outside of the "sniping mechanics in a rail shooter" niche.Disclaimer:  My only play through was on Medium difficulty and I did not try the multiplayer.

content:
Posted: January 1
												Booring game!  Better graphics that the first Ghost Warrior but that's about it.  Extremely linear, being directed from spot to the...yawn....next.  A little less linear that the first one but you are still being funnelled in one direction.  When aiming the Sniper rifle moves around so much (even with holding your breath) that it almost seems like your character has Parkinson or some other degenerating motor skill disease.  I've got a digital camera with a 35mm telephoto lens that I can hold steadier than the character can.  Regardless the game was repetitive and plain boring with a minimal story similar to the first Ghost Warrior that really didn’t matter.  The voice acting was mediocre also.  As with the first Ghost Warrior they did little with the background scenery.  I always try to explore the background in games and particular this game because you can tell that a lot of time was put into creating the good-looking jungle backgrounds.  However, even the buildings in this game were basically just boxes as they had very little inside them.  In most shooter games you would explore everything looking for loot, ammo or whatever was available in that particular game.  In this game there was little reason to explore as there was not much to find, the odd ammo here and there and the odd Health pack and some in game items.  I never came close to running out of ammo and didn't have to worry too much about my health.  The AI is pretty blind as you snipe an enemy next to another one and he doesn't notice.  For the most part I found this game way to boring and would snipe enemies to make them come to me so I could have a gun battle.  I also notice that in some in some situations that if you didn’t snipe the enemies in the order that the game wanted your compatriots on the ground somehow ended up getting compromised and you had repeat that scenario.  I also got stuck in a couple of places and had to restart that section.  That's the problem when creating linear, corridor shooter game with great backgrounds that aren't exploitable.  At one point I got stuck between the side of a building and a fence that I probably wasn't supposed to be able to explore and therefore could not get out and had to restart that section.Like the first Ghost Warrior couldn't finish it because I got bored with the linear gameplay, invisible walls and the very limited exploration of the environment usually necessary in most other FPS games.   Similar to the first Ghost Warrior I would give the graphics a 4/5 because you can tell that the artists put a lot of work into creating the jungle and other backgrounds.  It’s a pity they weren't better utilized.As for its boring and excruciating linearity gameplay I would give it 2/5.  Thank goodness I got both Ghost Warrior games on a Steam sale so I don’t feel so bad not finishing them.  That’s one of the better things about Steam; wait long enough for a really good game sale and if you didn’t like the game it’s not that big of a loss.

content:
Posted: February 14
												CI Games are amazing. This studio deserves way more recognition than it has. Hopefully Ghost Warrior 3, with its AAA billing, will help there.As for this game, great single player campaign. It's linear and that's great, I like that for single player shooters. Gorgeous graphics, very pretty. Good voice acting like in all CI games I've seen. Pretty good range of sniper rifles and a pistol for the short range. Has a detection system similar to Assassins Creed, so can be played very stealthily or openly aggressive. Story is very interesting, and the Serbian enemies in Act 2 are a breath of fresh air... but of course it has Russians and Jihadists too :) 10/10 from me, and very much looking forward to Ghost Warrior 3.

content:
Posted: January 8, 2015
												First things first, I bought this game solely for the multiplayer.This game is a great improvement over the first, but my singleplayer experience was ruined by various bugs and glitches.They started off small in the beginning of the game, small graphics glitches, floating objects, getting stuck on terrain, etc.Near the end of the game I ran into something awful. The game literally crashed my computer during one of the cutscenes. My pc can max this game without breaking a sweat, and this wasn't a crash to desktop, the computer completely turned off. When I powered back up my save file was corrupt. This is why I haven't even finished the single player yet, even though it is so short.Was I devasted? Not really, multiplayer was unaffected in any way. The multiplayer experience in Sniper Ghost Warrior 2 is an enjoyable one, if you enjoy sniping. Matches are around 20 minutes long and often never score higher than 15 or so kills. The sniping mechanics are really great in this game.Pros+Good mechanics+AR/SMG sections of first game are gone+Multiplayer is fun+Environments are very nice lookingCons-Poor story-Very buggy-Lack of a multiplayer community, theres hardly ever more than one server-Crashes for unknown reasons-Character models look horrendousAs I bought this game for the multiplayer, I would reccomend the multiplayer portion to a friend. As far as the single player experience goes, try out any of the Sniper Elite titles.

content:
Posted: January 1
												Booring game!  Better graphics that the first Ghost Warrior but that's about it.  Extremely linear, being directed from spot to the...yawn....next.  A little less linear that the first one but you are still being funnelled in one direction.  When aiming the Sniper rifle moves around so much (even with holding your breath) that it almost seems like your character has Parkinson or some other degenerating motor skill disease.  I've got a digital camera with a 35mm telephoto lens that I can hold steadier than the character can.  Regardless the game was repetitive and plain boring with a minimal story similar to the first Ghost Warrior that really didn’t matter.  The voice acting was mediocre also.  As with the first Ghost Warrior they did little with the background scenery.  I always try to explore the background in games and particular this game because you can tell that a lot of time was put into creating the good-looking jungle backgrounds.  However, even the buildings in this game were basically just boxes as they had very little inside them.  In most shooter games you would explore everything looking for loot, ammo or whatever was available in that particular game.  In this game there was little reason to explore as there was not much to find, the odd ammo here and there and the odd Health pack and some in game items.  I never came close to running out of ammo and didn't have to worry too much about my health.  The AI is pretty blind as you snipe an enemy next to another one and he doesn't notice.  For the most part I found this game way to boring and would snipe enemies to make them come to me so I could have a gun battle.  I also notice that in some in some situations that if you didn’t snipe the enemies in the order that the game wanted your compatriots on the ground somehow ended up getting compromised and you had repeat that scenario.  I also got stuck in a couple of places and had to restart that section.  That's the problem when creating linear, corridor shooter game with great backgrounds that aren't exploitable.  At one point I got stuck between the side of a building and a fence that I probably wasn't supposed to be able to explore and therefore could not get out and had to restart that section.Like the first Ghost Warrior couldn't finish it because I got bored with the linear gameplay, invisible walls and the very limited exploration of the environment usually necessary in most other FPS games.   Similar to the first Ghost Warrior I would give the graphics a 4/5 because you can tell that the artists put a lot of work into creating the jungle and other backgrounds.  It’s a pity they weren't better utilized.As for its boring and excruciating linearity gameplay I would give it 2/5.  Thank goodness I got both Ghost Warrior games on a Steam sale so I don’t feel so bad not finishing them.  That’s one of the better things about Steam; wait long enough for a really good game sale and if you didn’t like the game it’s not that big of a loss.

Posted: April 9
												Most broken and poorly written game I've ever played. There's so many things wrong with this game, I don't even know where to start. The game is more linear than the first Super Mario. Even on the hardest settings, this game takes your hand and walks you through the game, points out where most of the enemies are and there's even a radar system with a timer that tells you for how long you can be visible (almost in plain sight) to the enemy before he discovers you. Furthermore, the AI is non-existent and the enemies will often stand idle like nothing happened (despite you just killed several people in their vicinity) and wait for you to kill them. The story is very predictable all the way through and all the "surprises" in the story is not really surprising at all.Slight spoiler alert:I came to a point late in the game (act III, bad karma) where I am, after a cut scene, suddenly left without any weapons (which I just had before the cut scene), and I'm supposed to shoot down a helicopter within 5 seconds (which is kinda hard with no weapons.) I searched all over the area (it's a small area) and no weapons are to be found anywhere. So I guess my journey with this game ends here. I am unable to finish the story, which just adds to the disappointment this entire game experience has been.No price is low enough to make this game worthwhile your time. Go throw rocks in the nearest lake instead, that's gonna bring you much more entertainment than this game.

Posted: December 18, 2015
												Worst fricking game of all time, DO NOT BUY, SAVE YOURSELF THE MONEY and IGNORE. It has terrible performance, and a cruddy multiplayer. Can't even switch your pistol for an assault rifle, just in case! Also, the guy must wear like a frickin t-shirt because you die in like 1 hit, even on full health. The companion's AI is terrible, they do literally nothing for the player, or the game. The most common companion I've seen is Diaz and he gets an assault rifle, but goes for the least threatening guy when your cought. Checkpoints are few and far between at points where they are the most necessary, but every other hallway you encounter in the least necessary situations. You will find that even though your guy is a sniper and must have a strong arm, you cannot hold your rifle still even while crouching, which is when you are generally using it, and going prone generally leads to a tiny ledge in the way from bad level design, so you have to crouch and end up missing. I found myself often missing an easy target because a wooden plank is preventing me from going prone to be steadier. The graphics are acceptible, and in fact probably better than Call of Duty, and it has an interesting story, with a great sense of actually sniping, except for the stability. The best part is how your bullet drops with distance and is very affected by the wind, though I wish the little circle showing where the bullet will land would always be visible, as I often find myself looking around a target trying to find the dot. I've had frequent crashes, once caausing my entire computer to crash, so that is upsetting. Then after restarting your computer / the game, you need to sit through 4 different company thingies that you get at the beginning of most games that tell you who sponsored / help made the game and what engine it runs which are all unskippable. If they were skippable or only one or two, it would be OK, but there's four. FOUR! Thats over 20 seconds just waiting to get to the main menu!!! UNACCEPTABLE! So, to recap, I buy a game, have it not work, and have a serious game breaking graphical bug that gets fixed (without changing a thing) a few days later, only to have it crash, then sit through the company ad things all over again. I bought this game in the Bundle Stars Sniper Ghost Warrior Pack for $2.99, and now I know why it was priced that way. I can't believe they make you pay extra for DLC for one of the worst multiplayers ever!! 2 out of 10 stars.

												I was expecting a great looking, open-worldish, sniper shooter. Instead I got a linear restricted and buggy experience.  The fact that it was made in cryengine seems to mean nothing as its textures remind me of early cod. However as a casual shooter with no care for deep story or customisability, it isn't too bad.  The sniping is realistic, bullet drop and wind correction are amazingly accurate and the constant changing of vantage points give you motivation to take down as many targets as possible so you are clear to move.  It also has a slight crysis 1 / far cry 3 feel at times which can create a sense of comfort every now and then.

content:
Posted: June 16, 2014
												Remember how awesome Call Of Duty 4 was? Remember that level where you run through Pripyat as a sniper and take out the bad guy with your .50? Basically that. An entire game of that. Just that.With a bug list that rivals Goat Simulator and a story so easy to predict it left me wincing, Sniper: Ghost Warrior is back.The original Sniper: Ghost Warrior game was terrible. You can argue that all you want but having played it myself and not gotten a refund, I won't listen. The shooting mechanics offer some variety on the higher difficulty settings but overall the lack of challenging shots leaves a lot to be desired. The positioning aspect of the game amounts to walking along a predetermined path to painfully obvious hides. You take out a few waves of enemies with your high powered rifle. You move on to the next level.While this is no-punches-pulled for what the game advertises, I find it hard to justify the price when a much more competent competitor lets you enjoy shooting Hitler between the legs. If you want a ballistics simulation get either Sniper Elite v2 or Arma 3. If you want that Pripyat level of Call of Duty for an entire game, look no further.

content:
Posted: June 9, 2014
												Despite my dislike of modern military shooters and my added mental handicap when it comes to stealth gameplay - I really suck at stealth - I have a soft spot for any game that provides me with a good sniping experience. I mean the sniper is my favorite TF2 class and there's basically no realism about that, but I still enjoy it a lot.So I obviously picked up the original "Sniper: Ghost Warrior", despite what I've heard. Thankfully I only paid €1 for it because it really wasn't all that good. It had to much faffing about in between the actual sniping and seemed to want to thrust in more close-combat sections way to often, so I never finished it. Because in addition to that, the enemy AI was terribly unforgiving and could spot me from ludicrous distances. Likewise, I picked up "Sniper Elite V2" when it was offered for free on Steam a couple of days ago. And similar to the first "Sniper: Ghost Warrior" it seemed way to concerned with having me get more into the action and as such, I lost interest really quickly. It didn't help that it looked terrible, even for the time, with shoddy textures, horrible animation quality, ♥♥♥♥♥♥ aesthetic, etc. The sniping was fun yes, but at the cost of having an empty world that failed to engage me, so I stopped playing a couple of hours in.After that, I saw that Bundle Stars had "Sniper: Ghost Warrior 2" in a bundle over there, and even if it were the only game that piqued my interest in that particular bundle - which it wasn't - I could justify buying it for €3.66 instead of the full price of €20. Let me begin with saying that this game isn't worth €20, for multiple reasons. For one, the single-player campaign is criminally short. It took me 5.2 hours according to Steam to get through the story, including my personal ham-handedness when it comes to stealth, so I assume better gamers will finish it even quicker than that. The story is really disjointed and makes the world feel really small. I mean it takes place in the Philippines, Sarajevo and Tibet and yet the main players are all the same 5 guys all the time, it's like this was conceived as a James Bond game instead of a realistic depiction of arms dealing. It's also one of those tired old military bravado revenge stories, because we always need something personal about it to justify going off protocol. And while the graphics aren't bad per se (and I'm by no means a graphics ♥♥♥♥♥), I've seen better, especially out of the CryEngine 3. Worth noting is that the graphics in the pre-rendered cut-scenes are substantially worse than the in-game graphics, which is quite a feat. However, despite all those criticisms, I had fun playing it. Yes, it's horribly linear and bares little resemblance to what actual snipers have to do in real life, but here's the thing: I don't want my games to be recreations of life. I want my games to be escapism, and this provided me with what I sought for in a sniping game. It holds your hands a lot on the lower difficulties, but you can find a challenge here if you're looking for it. And for what it's worth, it really is committed to its theme of sniping and sneaking around. You can't absorb damage like in most other shooters and there isn't regenerating health. This is kind of an ambivalent point because for one it takes actual skill to get through the game, but on the other hand, it leads to a very tight level design that basically railroads you through if you need to use stealth. And with the aggressive linearity comes the heavy scripting of scenes that kill my immersion somewhat. I mean, there's an entire section where a cave system is collapsing around you and I never felt threatened, because a) I know it's a scripted sequence and b) my running speed is faster than the running speed of my AI partner.Speaking of that AI partner, it really adds a lot to the game. Especially in comparison to "Sniper Elite V2" where you were just this lone wolf going around Berlin. Even if the dialogue is just terrible, it just makes the game more appealing to me and opens up some characterization. I mean it's not very realistic to have a spotter armed with a regular assault rifle being able to take out targets at the same distance and accuracy as me with my sniper rifle, but I'll gladly overlook that in favor of having a bit of dialogue in there, regardless of its quality.The game doesn't seem to be too taxing, at least not on my machine. I cranked up all the settings to max and found that the game ran at 80-110 fps depending on locations, and this is with the CryEngine 3 so at least it's not badly optimized.My final verdict on this one is that I can recommend it to fans of sniping gameplay, but only if you can find it at a heavy discount, because 20 bucks for 5 hours is way too much. I paid less than a dollar for it when I bought the bundle, and for that it's great value.

												I bought this game primarily for the single player, with multiplayer being secondary.The single player was interesting, giving you a variety of options for dealing with a varying number of enemies in different scenarios. 												Warning: Possible spoilers. For 20 bucks? Hahaha. No. Lets start with the singleplayer. Let me just start by saying this game is no where near "story driven". The story is generic mess, with unbelievable hard to remember characters. The game really fails to draw you into the enviornment and really does a poor job of character development. If there is any. Most of the in game dialogue is just "good shot partner" and "nice kill". The rest of it is just you being scolded by your commander. The animations are incredibly janky and so is the voice acting..oh god the voice acting. Player models are compressed messes as well, and every enemy pretty much looks exactly the same. There is no more than two different player models for each type of enemy you face. The game also tries to dish (And I am assuming) heart wrenching drama by showing you the acts of genocide comitted in the Balkans in the 90s. To be honest, it was so generic it was very hard to take it seriously. The main villian is dull, and quiet weird. (Not in the good way) I saw myself constantly skipping the cutscenes, and just trying to get the missions over with. The "bossfight" is just some dude with aimbot. The game really is not challenging, and the detection system can be quite laggy at some points. You could be crawling on your belly in the bushes and be detected or crouching in the middle of a road and pretty much be a ninja. Overall I would give the story a 5/10. At some points it can be quite fun, but most of the time it is just dull, and feels more like a mini game or challenge instead of an actual story mission.The multiplayer is a bit of a different story, that is if you can find a server. I found that getting kills was quite satisfying, but lag and poor hit detection seemed to ruin it alot. Customization is probably the most disappointing thing about the MP. All you can do is choose a gun out of like 5-7 max, and a random player model from the story. There is alot of problems with connection and hacking, and the guess what the only guns are: thats right. Sniper rifles...instead of actually mixing it up and perhaps having just one sniper on one team and the rest regulars who the sniper must support, the decided to make everyone snipers, and just have them kill each other. Quite a disappointment. Overall I would give the game a 5/10. And I would recommend only picking it up when its on sale for a dirt cheap price for around 6 bucks like I did. Thats the only way you will get your moneys worth.

content:
Posted: June 9, 2014
												Despite my dislike of modern military shooters and my added mental handicap when it comes to stealth gameplay - I really suck at stealth - I have a soft spot for any game that provides me with a good sniping experience. I mean the sniper is my favorite TF2 class and there's basically no realism about that, but I still enjoy it a lot.So I obviously picked up the original "Sniper: Ghost Warrior", despite what I've heard. Thankfully I only paid €1 for it because it really wasn't all that good. It had to much faffing about in between the actual sniping and seemed to want to thrust in more close-combat sections way to often, so I never finished it. Because in addition to that, the enemy AI was terribly unforgiving and could spot me from ludicrous distances. Likewise, I picked up "Sniper Elite V2" when it was offered for free on Steam a couple of days ago. And similar to the first "Sniper: Ghost Warrior" it seemed way to concerned with having me get more into the action and as such, I lost interest really quickly. It didn't help that it looked terrible, even for the time, with shoddy textures, horrible animation quality, ♥♥♥♥♥♥ aesthetic, etc. The sniping was fun yes, but at the cost of having an empty world that failed to engage me, so I stopped playing a couple of hours in.After that, I saw that Bundle Stars had "Sniper: Ghost Warrior 2" in a bundle over there, and even if it were the only game that piqued my interest in that particular bundle - which it wasn't - I could justify buying it for €3.66 instead of the full price of €20. Let me begin with saying that this game isn't worth €20, for multiple reasons. For one, the single-player campaign is criminally short. It took me 5.2 hours according to Steam to get through the story, including my personal ham-handedness when it comes to stealth, so I assume better gamers will finish it even quicker than that. The story is really disjointed and makes the world feel really small. I mean it takes place in the Philippines, Sarajevo and Tibet and yet the main players are all the same 5 guys all the time, it's like this was conceived as a James Bond game instead of a realistic depiction of arms dealing. It's also one of those tired old military bravado revenge stories, because we always need something personal about it to justify going off protocol. And while the graphics aren't bad per se (and I'm by no means a graphics ♥♥♥♥♥), I've seen better, especially out of the CryEngine 3. Worth noting is that the graphics in the pre-rendered cut-scenes are substantially worse than the in-game graphics, which is quite a feat. However, despite all those criticisms, I had fun playing it. Yes, it's horribly linear and bares little resemblance to what actual snipers have to do in real life, but here's the thing: I don't want my games to be recreations of life. I want my games to be escapism, and this provided me with what I sought for in a sniping game. It holds your hands a lot on the lower difficulties, but you can find a challenge here if you're looking for it. And for what it's worth, it really is committed to its theme of sniping and sneaking around. You can't absorb damage like in most other shooters and there isn't regenerating health. This is kind of an ambivalent point because for one it takes actual skill to get through the game, but on the other hand, it leads to a very tight level design that basically railroads you through if you need to use stealth. And with the aggressive linearity comes the heavy scripting of scenes that kill my immersion somewhat. I mean, there's an entire section where a cave system is collapsing around you and I never felt threatened, because a) I know it's a scripted sequence and b) my running speed is faster than the running speed of my AI partner.Speaking of that AI partner, it really adds a lot to the game. Especially in comparison to "Sniper Elite V2" where you were just this lone wolf going around Berlin. Even if the dialogue is just terrible, it just makes the game more appealing to me and opens up some characterization. I mean it's not very realistic to have a spotter armed with a regular assault rifle being able to take out targets at the same distance and accuracy as me with my sniper rifle, but I'll gladly overlook that in favor of having a bit of dialogue in there, regardless of its quality.The game doesn't seem to be too taxing, at least not on my machine. I cranked up all the settings to max and found that the game ran at 80-110 fps depending on locations, and this is with the CryEngine 3 so at least it's not badly optimized.My final verdict on this one is that I can recommend it to fans of sniping gameplay, but only if you can find it at a heavy discount, because 20 bucks for 5 hours is way too much. I paid less than a dollar for it when I bought the bundle, and for that it's great value.

content:
Posted: February 6, 2014
												Good game. Absolutely the best sniper game i've played. However i think the single campaign was too short. Finished the entire game plus DLC in about 12 hours. That's not too much considering the price for the game.I also tried some multiplayer but that was just too lame.I don't blame the lameness on the developers though, but on the community.Most of the people just wanted to spawn, find a good spot and then lie there staring at the building with the enemies on the other side of the map until they eventually spotted an enemey and fired or got fired upon and died without noticing where it came from.To add another dimension to this, and perhaps to counter this kind of boring gameplay, the developers have added the possibility to cross an open field and get to the enemies house on the other side.That was a good thing i thought. That would add a risk of camping and just staring down a scope, or hiding too well so you cant get a good overview - for ex to spot an enemy crossing.Crossing the field to the enemys would indeed be risky, but if you manage you would get an advantage on people staring blindly down their scopes. This could also be a benefit for your own team, as you would 'stir things up' in the enemies building, causing them to move and thereby opening up shots for your team.However, this interesting aspect of the game was utterly crushed by the people who just want to find a cozy corner, camp it out and hope to get a lucky shot.The crushing consisted of public yelling in chat "No crossing! No crossing! No crossing!".If their will was not obliged, they whent to the length of killing their own team if they reached the enemies building.So, if you're feeling bored and want to become even more bored. Go play Ghost Warrior 2 Multiplayer, cause boredom is all you'll get out of it.Splendid single campaign though. Well made sniper game well worth trying out. But abit low on play hours for the price.

content:
Posted: September 29, 2015
												If you're a fan of these types of games, then I think you'll be pleased with this one.  I sure was!Ever since I was a kid, snipers and their trade have always piqued my interest.  When I was old enough to get my first Airsoft Gun, I chose one modeled after the M24 Sniper Rifle used by Marine Corps Scout Snipers.  So, when I discovered the first Sniper: Ghost Warrior, I played and loved it.  When this sequel came out, I played, and also loved it.From a gameplay standpoint, it's what you'd expect out of this type of game; low, slow and stealthy.  At times you run into a few "WTF Moments," where you crawl past an enemy who clearly should've seen you and didn't, but that comes down to AI more than anything else.  It's still very enjoyable though; especially on higher difficulties.Graphically and auditorily, I found myself very, very pleased.  On full ultra settings the game looks beautiful, and the sound effects are incredibly immersing as well.  The two combine to make a very involving atmosphere in my opinion.The storyline is pretty typical, but, I imagine it's hard to come up with one for this type of game that HASN'T been done before, LOL.  That didn't stop me from enjoying it though, or putting myself in the shoes of the main character you play.All in all, I think fans of this type of game will enjoy it.

content:
Posted: February 16, 2015
												I'll probably be writing the only 100% positive review for this game, but I'm sick of seeing people slate it so I felt the need. This is based on never having played Sniper : Ghost Warrior, and from my current experience of that game I'm no more inclined to agree with all the people slating this sequel. I can perhaps see why it's been slated - no awkward fiddly grappling hook that you struggle to remember the rather unintuitive controls for (yes plural - you first have to select it, then you have to activate it, then you have to press yet more keys to use it). But hello, you really enjoy being a sniper, you see a game called "Sniper 2 : Ghost Warrior", you just want to go sniping! Or am I missing the point somewhere. The game does feel a little on rails, but that's still fine with me - it still lets you explore a bit but if you wander too far you get a 5 second countdown to get back to the mission area. The level of detail within the game is really quite something. The locations are very varied and I felt like James Bond going all over the world on my missions - if not always to the most glamorous of locales. Also the developer has made a far better use of the Far Cry 3 engine than the developers of Far Cry 3 itself have. One rather nice difference between this game and Far Cry 3 are the lack of bullet proof leaves.If you want an all action title with a sandbox feature, go to Just Cause 2. If you really, really enjoy picking people off from afar, get this game. It is not that long, but in this case it's definitely quality not quantity. The game feels polished and finished. How many games can you really honestly say that for in this day and age?

content:
Posted: January 26, 2016
												Basically a decent arcade shooter with a strong console feel to it. Visually, it's quite decent, the audio is fairly immersive although the weapon sounds are so-so.The missions are extremely linear but well designed, alternating stealth and action.Compared to the "big" titles of the same genre like COD, the difference mostly shows in the way the player character is managed. Here you never feel like you have a choice. It's basically a number of different levels to beat as they were designed to be beaten. Stray from the path and you'll get killed. Games with a larger budget like COD manage to hide this fact much more effectively. Supposedly you can shoot enemies behind cover but in practice you can't (most military bullets will pass through wood, not in this game). Except for glass.All in all a decent entry in a fairly crowded genre.

content:
Posted: February 8, 2016
												This is a glitched filled, unfair enemy advantaged, let down. It's got great potential and the 'Sneaky Beaky Like' is rather fun at times when choosing to sneak around and take the set paths rather than killing them all and compromising your presences, but their is multiple parts straight from the very first mission that are just glitched; I.E Partner's not moving and having to either restart the last check point, or move on by yourself which can prove challenging because the mission is led out too follow him, mission objectives not disappearing as if uncompleted, enemys not dying although are dead (meaning they're still moving about but not shooting nor do bullets hit them (ghosts) ) and the graphics, i mean the graphics are abysmal, with scopes and oval shapes having sharp edges like a octagon, pixelated walls and textures and no difference betwen A.I faces, there is like three or four different faces for all A.I bar special characters, the graphics look like something you would expect from a game that came out the same time the Xbox 360 was released, so something from 2006...okay maybe thats a bit harsh, 2008 graphics. I am a big fan of the Sniper Franchise, and knowing what they're capable of with their Sniper Elite line you just wonder what went wrong because in my opinion the Sniper Elites esepcially Sniper Elite 2 is so much better, for instance why doesn't this have X-Ray bullet Cam like Elite, i mean we know they can do it; furthermore why doesn't this game have a more greater range of weapons, for instance #MINI UNIMPORTANT SPOILER ALERT'. you go back in time at one point and have the same secondary. 'END OF SPOILER' It all feels lazy like why couldn't they have of just mixed that up for us, i know it's small but it's the small things that are nice in games. It's like the makers and designers just couldn't be bothered. You get spotted at stupid times like the enemys are god and see all, you can get spotted to where as your partner won't, even though you are following his orders and doing what he's doing. Bullet Cam is Scarse and pointless (due to no X-Ray). In all truth i only bought this game because it was so cheap (£3.99) in the sales. Now the Multiplayer, having just come from multiplayer i would like to say it's better than the campaign BUT that doesn't mean it is good, it is seriously hard too find people and well find people in a match, i had to make my own server which was easy as lemons and thankfully people still joined but still. Also just like the campaign it is seriously broke, i only played one match and one guy was out the map killing, another was shooting through sandbags so you couldn't see him but he could see you. I know it is meant to be a sneaky game but unless you get close or have a massive understanding of the maps and good places of where people will hide it is mere impossible to find someone at range. There is more guns in multplayer, there is 5 in the campaign i think as far as i can remeber and there is like 3 maybe 4 extra in multiplayer, no choice of secondary still this is merely primarys, and there is no damage difference #MINI UNIMPORTANT SPOILER' A VSS which is a small built in silenced sniper rifle has the same power as a 50. Cal 'END OF SPOILER' So if you're going to play it just use that as you're silenced. Maps are, small but I'll give them this, they were rather nicely detailed and layed out, basically what they did was mirrow the map to either side with a mini risky bridge in the middle that you can cross but got to be lucky due to over exposure, no specials like grenades or smokes, you dont have binoculars and night vision like in campaign. It is like you have been sent into battle on budget, and well that the games been made on a budget having all the issues it's got, and they have obviously done nothing about it with the glitches and brakes seeming it has been out for years now.I know it was a glitch filled game from playing the demo on Xbox when it was going on release; a part of me did think (well it was a demo so maybe they've fixed it) no, they have not and as I'v said it's great potential is let down by the lazy makers. Knowing what such potential they have from past games this is just disappointing and i shake my head at them. SO in all if you dont mind glitches and out dated 7 year old graphics and lazy game making then have at it, otherwise i'd openly recommend buying it STRICTLY at good price on the sales as it is not worth it or if you've got a couple bucks left and want a Sneaky game. Or just don't do it. DissapointingSPOILERS FROM NOW ON (mini ones)3 Acts.3 Missions in Act 1 & 2.4 In Act Three.Me being sneaky cause i do play these games properly, took me about 4-5 hours on medium, probably do it in 2-3 on easy and 6-7 on hard.There is collectables, two different types being Gold Statue's and Tape Reels, think 4 of each on each mission but I did not bother with going round collecting them though as i knew i wasn't going to heavily bother with this game once completed.

content:
Posted: July 18, 2013
												If you get this game on sale - great. If you pay anything over $10 however you'll be greatly disappointed.I honestly thought that City Interactive was going to use this oppotunity at a sequel to address the issues and lukewarm reactions to the first game. Unfortunately it appears that most of the game's budget was siphoned into using the CryEngine 3 graphics engine (Crysis 2) but despite having such a proven utility at their disposal they only managed to create an alright looking game that still encounters consistent technical issues ranging from texture pop, to visual anomolies, and textures just not loading properly.Beyond this the gameplay has remained much the same save for the exclusion of multiple player characters and sections devouted to being traditional first person shooters. This is a good thing though as the first game executed these things terribly.The characters are bland, the voice acting is crap, the story is standard military-thriller fare and isn't original or groundbreaking, and the whole thing might take you three or four hours to complete...overall Ghost Warrior 2 is just a mediocre experience.  As previously stated. If you get it for under $10 it'll probably serve as a nice distraction but don't expect to be blown away.

												It's an all around decent game.  Sometimes it gets a bit dry, but sometimes you feel as though you might actually care about the characters.  Essentially it's just a modern hash out of Sniper Elite without the bullet cams.  Perhaps the best part is that the enemies actually react appropriately to being shot with a high cailbre rifle; they die.  This is unlike Sniper Elite where many enemies will walk off one, two, and even three center of mass shots.My favorite aspect is that it takes the player to a warzone that has never been explored by the world of gaming, and that is the break-up of Yugoslavia.  That alone breathed enough life into the game to make it seem decent enough to play through.
